On floor patient reports no complaints. She has been eating and

has had no change in bladder or bowel habits. She does report 
however that she has had been drinking more tea and water 
recently. She is very pleasant and is AOX3; is a former ___.

Final Report
INDICATION:  ___ with mechanical fall, fell onto right side, 
with right hip
pain  // fracture
 
COMPARISON:  Prior exam dated ___.
 
FINDINGS: 
 
AP pelvis and two views of the right hip were provided.  There 
is left hip
arthroplasty partially imaged which appears aligns normally and 
without signs
of hardware failure.  Chronic deformities involving the inferior 
pubic rami
are again noted.  Right hip aligns normally.  Vascular 
calcification noted. 
Bony pelvic ring appears intact.  SI joints are symmetric and 
normal.
 
IMPRESSION: 
 
No acute findings.

EXAMINATION:  CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST
 
INDICATION:  ___ with mechanical fall witnessed onto right side, 
with right
sided hematoma, no LOC, not on blood thinners
 
TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast helical multidetector CT was performed. 
Soft tissue
and bone algorithm images were generated.  Coronal and sagittal 
reformations
were then constructed.
 
DOSE:  Total DLP (Body) = 625 mGy-cm.

CT SPINE

COMPARISON:  CT cervical spine ___.
 
FINDINGS: 
 
Mild anterolisthesis of C4 on C5 and retrolisthesis of C6 on C7 
is chronic. 
No acute fractures are identified.  Multilevel degenerative 
changes with
anterior osteophytes and disc space narrowing are present and 
unchanged. 
There is no prevertebral soft tissue swelling.There is no 
cervical
lymphadenopathy by size criteria.  The visualized thyroid gland 
is
unremarkable.  Prominent biapical pleural-parenchymal scarring 
and
calcifications are unchanged from prior exam.  The visualized 
aerodigestive
tract is grossly unremarkable.  Prominent atherosclerotic 
calcification of the
bilateral carotid bifurcations are noted.
 
IMPRESSION:
 
 
1. No acute fracture or traumatic malalignment.
2. Multilevel degenerative changes, unchanged from prior exam.

CT HEAD

Final Report
EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST
 
INDICATION:  ___ with mechanical fall witnessed onto right side, 
with right
sided hematoma, no LOC, not on blood thinners
 
TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the brain were obtained 
without
contrast.
 
DOSE:  Total DLP (Head) = 803 mGy-cm.
 
COMPARISON:  Head CT ___.
 
FINDINGS: 
 
There is no evidence of acute large territorial infarction, 
hemorrhage, edema,
or mass effect. Ventricles and sulci are prominent, consistent 
with
age-related involutional changes.  Periventricular subcortical 
white matter
hypodensities are nonspecific but compatible with chronic small 
vessel
ischemic changes and unchanged from prior exam.
There is no evidence of fracture.  Extensive calcification of 
carotid siphons
is present.  Partial opacification of right mastoid air cells is 
noted.  The
visualized portion of the paranasal sinuses,left mastoid air 
cells, and middle
ear cavities are clear.  Mild right temporal scalp hematoma is 
identified
without underlying skull fracture.
 
IMPRESSION:
 
 
1. No acute intracranial abnormality on noncontrast head CT.  
Specifically no
intracranial hemorrhage.

CXR 

EXAMINATION:

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with fall found to have elevated 
WBC.  // Eval
for cardiopulmonary process

COMPARISON:  ___
 
FINDINGS: 
 
The patient is somewhat rotated.  The lungs remain 
hyperinflated.  Biapical
pleural thickening is noted.  No new focal consolidation is 
seen.  No pleural
effusion or pneumothorax is seen. The cardiac and mediastinal

stable.  Partially imaged bilateral humeral prostheses noted.
 
IMPRESSION:

MICRIOBIOLOGY
========================

Allergies: morphine / Keflex
Resident: ___ ___ Intern: ___ ___
Code Status: Do not resuscitate (DNR/DNI) molst in chart
Microbiology Results(last 7 days) ___
__________________________________________________________
___ 10:13 am URINE

                            **FINAL REPORT ___

   URINE CULTURE (Final ___:    NO GROWTH. 

 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ pleasant year old female s/p recent left hip revision 
hemiarthoplasty presents from nursing home with mechanical fall, 
found to have profound hyponatremia (118) and likely UTI, and 
___. It was determined patient likely had prerenal ___ prior to 
admission, and during hospital stay while hyponatremika improved 
from 118 to 128 source of hypoantremia remained unclear, with 
belief being patient may have suffered from SIADH vs reset 
osmostat. Patient discharged on 1 L fluid restriction with plans 
for close PCP followup, and her home SSRi was stopped.  

HOSPITAL COURSE BY ISSUE
==================
#Hyponatremia: Likely chronic in setting of poor po intake, 
possible volume down, and confusion from UTI. initially patient 
was fluid restricted for concern siadh. Patient was given 500 cc 
boluses but now with ___ improvement 118 on admission to 129, 
leading team to believe hypovolemic hyponatremia in setting of 
poor po intake after recent hip surgery as cause. However, 
patient then subseqeutnly had drop in ___, with urine osmolality 
showed ~ 400. AS a result, patient was fluid restricted, with ___ 
hovering around ~140, with resolution ___ below. Ultimately it 
was determined as despite fluid boluses and fluid restriction 
and given lack of symptoms, patient may have had a reset 
osmostat as well. Her home fluoxetine was stopped, and TSH was 
checked at 12 (FT4 1.0); home synthroid was uptitrated to 75 mcg 
from 50mcg as a result.   

# UTI, leukocytosis: CXR clear. WBC 13.4 on admision, ~ 7 on 
___ after treating uti. Patient was on bactrim ___t 
___ for unclear reason, switched to cipro in house. patient 
afebrile, has some hesitancy symptoms, mild positive u/a. 
Leukocytosis now improving. Urince cultures were negative but 
given fact patient came in on bactrim and improvement in WBC 
continued cipro /17, d7 = ___ given improvement since starting 
antibx

___: Cr 1.4 from 1.0 baseline, likely pre renal. It was 
believed she ahd a prerenal ATN immediately prior to admission 
as while giving her fluidis initially during her stay helped her 
___ it worsened her Cr. However, by discharge, Cr had started to 
downtrend to 1.2. 

# Hypertension: Home lisinopril was held due to ___ above. She 
was intermittently hypertensive overnight in the setting of 
pain. She recieved oxycodone prn as below.  

#Trauma workup s/p mechanical fall: Hip x-rays Negative, no 
fractures. Patient s/o ___ left hip hemiarthoplasty (left 
hip s/p hip replacement ___ years prior) Pain control with 
oxycodone. 

# Hx depression: Continued hoem fluoxetine, then stopped ___ 
possible SIADH above 

# Hypothyroid: Continued home synthroid. TSH in house was 12; 
however free T4 was wnl. ___ hypothyroidism as possible 
etiology of hypoantremia above, patient was uptitrated to 75 mcg 
synthroid on d/c. 

# Osteoporosis: Continued calcium, vitamin D 

# Pain control: Continued home meds save for hydromorphone; 
switched to oxycodone prn, can switch back on d/c. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
==============================
-Patient to end ciprofloxacin on ___
-Please check ___, Cr at next PCP appointment, ___ on d/c 128, 
1.2
-Patient used short term oxycodone in house; she can resume her 
prior pain regimen thereafter. Rx short course to last until PCP 
followup as patient feared ALF would require rx to fill.  
-Patient's home lisinopril discontinued, if Cr returns to normal 
on d/c woul restart
-Home synthroid increased to 75 mcg from 50 mcg given TSH of 12 
(elevated) and hyponatremia above (however free T4 1). Given 
just subclinical hypothyroidism on labs; would recheck TSH and 
Free T4 in 3 weeks; if patient hyperthyroid decrease synthroid 
back to 50 mcg. 
-Patient's home SSRI stopped due to hyponatremia above. 
-Patient discharged on 1 L fluid restriction; if patient appears 
dry on F/U appointment and ___ improving, would liberalize 
restriction.

Home With Service

Hypovolemic Hyponatremia
UTI

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You came to the hospital because you fell. At the hospital, it 
was determined that you had no fractures but your sodium was 
very low, and our medical team felt you were dehydrated. In the 
hospital we gave your IV fluids and your sodium improved. We ask 
that you follow up with your primary care physician to monitor 
your sodium level and kidney function. We also also discharging 
you with a short taper of oxycodone for pain in your hip; after 
this you should go back on the pain regimen your assisted living 
facility is giving you. Lastly, we are giving you an antiobiotic 
for a possible UTI (you were taking another antibitotic at home 
which we changed). This antibiiotic is called ciprofloxacin, and 
you will take it until ___.  

We wish you all the best!
-You ___ Care Team

CXR:
AP PORTABLE CHEST ___ AT 12:58 P.M. 
  
HISTORY: Dyspnea with left-sided chest tube. 
  
COMPARISON: Multiple priors, the most recent dated ___. 
  
FINDINGS: Compared to the ___ PET-CT, there has been 
progressive enlargement of the effusion and progressive 
rightward mediastinal shift on all successive radiographs 
including today's. There is near complete opacification of the 
left hemithorax with only a small residual aerated lung noted 
laterally in the lower aspects of the hemithorax in the region 
of the indwelling pleural drain. The right lung is largely 
clear. The mediastinum cannot be adequately assessed. The 
osseous structures are grossly unremarkable. 
  
IMPRESSION: Massive left pleural effusion with near-complete 
opacification of the left lung as above. 
CT Chest:
COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY OF THE THORAX 
  
INDICATION: Worsening malignant effusion, potential loculations. 

  
TECHNIQUE: Volumetric thin section CT over the entire thorax in 
inspiration, 
no administration of contrast material, multiplanar 
reconstructions. 
  
COMPARISON: PET-CT of ___. 
  
FINDINGS: The pre-existing left-sided fluid collection has 
increased in 
extent. It now occupies most of the volume of the left 
hemithorax. In the 
basal dorsal regions of the fluid collection, a single septation 
is seen. 
Otherwise, no septations or loculations can be visualized. The 
fluid is 
contained in a sac of thickened and hypodense pleura. At the 
basolateral 
parts of this pleural site, a laterally positioned drain is 
visualized. The pleural sac displaces the mediastinum to the 
right. Several high density and enlarged lymph nodes are seen, 
notably at the ventral circumference of the pleural sac, at the 
level of the aortic arch and in the aortopulmonary window. 
Similar structures are also seen in the subcarinal region. Mild 
pericardial effusion, small hiatal hernia. In the right lung, a 
small subpleural nodules has newly occurred (3,17). No other 
lung lesions are seen. 
  
IMPRESSION: Increase of the left fluid collection that shows a 
single 
loculation in the dorsal basal area. Massively thickened nodular 
pleura. 
Extensive mediastinal and perilesional lymphadenopathy. Massive 
displacement of the mediastinum. Newly appeared right lung 
nodules. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
In the ED, initial vs were: T 97, HR 100, BP 142/66, RR 16, Sat 
99% ra. U/S with effusion. CXR with L whiteout. CT chest with 
new anterior effusion. Patient was discussed with IP who said 
they would see the patient on the floor. Patient remained stable 
on room air.  
.  
 
.
# Dyspnea: Given imaging, likely ___ lung collapse from 
worsening malignant pleural effusion. The effusion appears to 
have an anterior and posterior compartment. The posterior 
compartment is being drained by her pleurex which is working 
appropriately. On arrival the the floor the patient was seen by 
___. They noted that her posterior pigtail was draining well. 
They did an anterior thoracentesis and drained 1.1L of 
serosanguinous fluid.  IP was concerned for bleeding into her 
pleural cavity, but thoracentesis is serosangionous so more 
likely malignant effusion. No fever, chills or leukocytosis 
concerning for infection.  The patient's repeat CXR 
post-thoracentesis showed mild improvement in aeration and 
mediastinal shift.  The follow up CXR from day after 
thoracentesis showed reaccumulation of the fluid.  The patient 
had no 02 requirement and 02 sat ranged 93-100%.  
-will f/u with IP the week of discharge for likely drain 
placement. 
.  
# Thyroid Cancer: Spoke to patient's outpatient oncologist and 
the patient has failed sorafenib, her only future option would 
be chemo. However, per her outpatient PCP notes, the patient is 
not interested in future chemo.  
-outpatient ONC follow up.  
.  
# Hypoparathyroidism with hypocalcemia:  Patient continued on 
home calcitriol and calcium.  Calcium 7.7 on DOA.
.
#Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation: Patient not anticoagulated as 
outpatient.  She was continued on 200 amiodarone daily and 
metoprolol.  
.  
# Hypothyroidism:  Patient continued on levothyroxine. 
.  
# Anemia: Patient's HCT decreased by 6 overnight.  CXR was 
repeated and did not show evidence of hemothrorax.  Repeat HCT 
increased so likely lab error and dilutional effect of IVF.  
Also, patient had some mild bleeding with thoracentesis.

Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hospital with shortness of breath.  We found 
that your left lung was collapsed from fluid builing up.  Our 
interventional pulmonologists drained the fluid from your lung 
and you remained stable.  We would like you to follow up with 
your pulmonologists very closely for management.
.
We made NO changes to your medications.
.
Please follow up with your doctors as below.  The pulmonary 
doctors ___ on ___ to schedule your follow up 
appointment.  If you do not hear from them, please call the 
pulmonary clinic on ___.
.
If you have worsening shortness of breath, fever, chills, chest 
pain, blood in your sputum, back pain, nausea, vomiting or any 
other symptoms that are concerning to you please call your 
doctor or come to the emergency room.

History of Present Illness:
HPI(4): Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a history of
Crohn's colitis s/p terminal ileum resection ___ and colectomy
in ___ who presented with abdominal pain and BRBPR.

About 2 days ago on ___, she started to have dark-colored
stools, which are very unusual for her, and then BRBPR (drops of
blood in the toilet and blood on the toilet paper). At baseline,
she normally has ___ stools a day, but sometimes it goes up to
___. She feels like her frequency of stooling is slightly 
above
baseline and greater than 10 per day. At the same time that she
developed the bloody stools, she started to have LLQ pain as 
well
as rectal pain. The pain is both aching and sharp, constant, and
non-radiating. It does feel like her Crohn's. Nothing makes it
significantly better or worse. The pain has been associated with
nausea and vomiting. She has had a few bouts of emesis with
bright red blood. Her last PO intake was a shake on ___
afternoon. On ___ she was able to eat a meatball and some
carrots. 
She woke up sweaty and hot on ___ night. She did not take
her temperature.

Her frequency of stooling has been at her baseline of ___ stools
per day. She also started to have LLQ pain associated with
nausea, vomiting, and coffee-ground emesis. She has only been
able to take in Pedialyte for the past 2 days. She has been
having subjective fevers at home.

Since arrival in the ED, her pain is unchanged. She feels a
little less nauseated since receiving antiemetics and pain meds. 


She denies lightheadedness, dizziness, chest pain, shortness of
breath, or palpitations. No coughing. No dysuria. No rashes or
skin changes. No lower extremity edema. She has been walking
around without issues.

For her Crohn's, she is followed by Dr. ___ at the
___. She last saw her about 6 months ago and had a
sigmoidoscopy which appeared normal. 
Currently she takes nutraceutical supplements for her Crohn's.
The last time she was on therapy for her Crohn's was ___ years
ago when she was on Remicaide. It worked well for her Crohn's 
but
she developed sinus infections so discontinued it. Her Crohn's
has been in remission since then.
Prior to Remicaide she was on ___, and prior to that she was on
Pentasa.

Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and underwent R leg angiogram, plasty 
of R popliteal artery on ___, and a repeat R leg angiogram, 
re-plasty of R popliteal artery, stenting of R popliteal artery 
on ___. You are now stable for discharge home.

MEDICATION:
• Take Aspirin 81mg once daily
• If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
• Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
• You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort
WHAT TO EXPECT:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
• Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows 
every ___ hours throughout the day and night
• Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
• It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
• Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
• It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
• To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

ACTIVITIES:
• When you go home, you may walk and use stairs
• You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
• Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area 
• No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
• After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
• After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
• No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
• Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
• Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
• New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
• Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
• Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call 
___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

Oncology Service for elective resection. On ___, the

washing, which went well without complication (please see the

the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor NPO, on IV fluids and 
antibiotics, with a foley catheter, and Morphine PCA for pain 
control.  The patient was hemodynamically stable.
Psych: Patient has a history of early ___ and anxiety.

1 and Geriatric Service was called in order to help managing 
patient acute post op delirium. Geriatric's recommendations were 
followed, opioids were minimized, patient was given Zyprexa and 
Ativan for agitations. Patient's mental status started to 
improve on POD 4 and gradually returned to her baseline prior 
discharge. 
Neuro: The patient received Morphine PCA immediately post op. 
She was unable to use PCA and was started on Morphine prn. 
Opioids were minimized for treatment of delirium, IV Tylenol and 
Lidocaine patch were provided for pain control. When tolerating 
PO patient was started on Tramadol for pain control with good 
effect.
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirrometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization.
GI: Post-operatively, the patient was made NPO/NGT with IV 
fluids. NGT was removed on POD 2. Diet was advanced when 
appropriate to regular post gastrectomy diet on POD 9. Nutrition 
service followed the patient and education about diet 
modification was provided to the patient and her family.

was adjusted when necessary.  Electrolytes were routinely 
followed, and repleted when necessary.
ID: The patient's white blood count and fever curves were 
closely watched for signs of infection. Wound was evaluated 
daily and no signs or symptoms of infection were noticed.
Endocrine: No issues

routinely; no transfusions were required.
Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay; was encouraged to get 
up and ambulate as early as possible.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
post gastrectomy diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, 
and pain was well controlled.  The patient received discharge 
teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

1. Complete occlusion of the left subclavian artery by a large

atherosclerotic plaque at its origin is incompletely evaluated 
in this exam but raises concern for subclavian steal syndrome. 
Evaluation of differential upper extremity blood pressure should 
be performed. Dense calcification was also seen at the level of 
occlusion in the non enhanced chest CT from ___, 
suggesting chronicity. 
2. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome. 
3. No esophageal extravasation of contrast or penumomediastinum 
identified.  However, this supine study is limited for 
assessment of esophageal perforation and an upper GI study 
should be performed if there is further clinical concern. 
4. Bibasilar ground-glass opacities with nodular components, 
more prominent in the right base, are slightly worsened than in 
the previous exam. Given short term progression this likely 
represents infection versus aspiration.  However, continued 
follow up after treatment is recommended to assess for 
resolution of nodular component in this patient with history of 
esophageal cancer.

IMPRESSION:  Diffuse distal common carotid and carotid 
bifurcation plaque with no significant stenosis.  Reversal of 
flow is seen in the left vertebral artery consistent with a 
known subclavian occlusion.

There is an ulceration measuring approximately 2.2 cm on the 
plantar aspect of the left foot at the level of the

erosion at the base of the first metatarsal medially.  If this 
corresponds to the site of the ulcer, this could reflect 
osteomyelitis.  Otherwise, this represents a nonspecific erosion 
which could be seen in the setting of an inflammatory 
arthropathy or gout.  There are mild degenerative changes of the 
left foot.  A moderate-sized plantar calcaneal spur is noted.

On ___ ___ was taken urgently to the operating room 
and underwent
1. Urgent coronary artery bypass graft x4:  Left internal 
mammary artery to left anterior descending artery, and saphenous 
vein grafts to the diagonal, obtuse marginal,and distal right 
coronary arteries. 2. Endoscopic harvesting of the long 
saphenous vein. Please see operative report for further surgical 
details. She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to

optimized. Chest tubes and pacing wires were discontinued per 
protocol without incident. She was transferred to the step down 
unit for further management. Physical Therapy was consulted for 
evaluation of strength and mobility. The remainder of her 
hospital course was essentially uneventful. By  the time of pod#

wounds healing. She was discharged to ___

Brief Hospital Course:
# SOB: Has chronic systolic heart failure (EF 20%) Likely due to 
CHF exacerbation which patient has been admitted for multiple 
times. Precipitating factor likely nutrional and fluid 
restriction non-compliance (see disposition at end of discharge 
___. Unlikely ischemia as had no EKG changes, no arrythmias 
on telemetry, and no evidence of infection such as UTI or PNA. 
Hypervolemic on exam. Patient was diuresed with a lasix gtt drip 
and was negative ___ L and down ___ kg in weight prior to 
disscharge. Her beta blocker was continued and imdur was added.
Her digoxin was discontinued after supratherapeutic digoxin 
level was discovered, and was restarted on discharge on a 
___ schedule. Nutriton consult was obtained 
and patient was given information on sodium and fluid restricted 
diets. Kept daily weights, kept on sodium and fluid restricted 
diet and strict Is and Os. Discharged on torsamide 40 mg PO BID. 
On discharge, she was no orthopnic or SOB and satting well on 
room air.

# CAD: Denies chest pain. Unlikely ACS, as she no significant 
EKG changes from previous. Her cardiac enzymes were likely 
elevated in the setting of CHF resulting in mild demand ischem 
and chronic renal failure. Patient has had similar tropnin 
elevation on previous admissions for CHF exacerbations. She was 
continued on ASA, beta blocker, imdur, and plavix. She has an 
allergy to lipitor, but her lipid panel showed 
hypertriglyceridemia and LDL not at goal and so she was started 
on pravastatin, which she tolerated well.   

#. Hypotension - pt runs in SBPs of ___, likely in setting of 
her chronic systolic heart failure. continued BB, ACEI, imdur 
with lower BP hold parameters.  
 
# Myelofibrosis: Patient had elevated nucleated RBCs on her 
blood smear. Heme-onc followed patient while in house. Her 
danazol was stopped during this hospital admission. Patient also 
had some issues with bleeding from heparin SQ and some 
associated mild thrombocytopenia (platelets 120s => 100s), so it 
was discontinued and she was switched to pneumoboots. Receives 
Aranesp 25 mcg qweekly, last dose ___. She will follow in 
outpatient ___ clinic for her Aranesp injections  

# Lower extremity edema: R > L lower leg edema, likely chronic 
in setting of SVG removal from R leg. No recent travel. No 
evidence of DVT on LENIS.  

#. Asthma - continued albuterol and fluticasone and tiotroprium. 
 

#. Hyperlipidemia - started on pravastatin which was tolerated 
well.

#. Diabetes - diet controlled with diabetic/cardiac diet. HISS 
not required for this patient.

# Disposition: Patient was discharged to home with many 
medication changes, including medications directed towards 
improving her CHF treatment (imdur, torsamide, digoxin regimen 
change) and had follow up with multiple providers. When nursing 
was doing discharge preparations for the patient in the 
afternoon, patient was reportedly angry that she could not be 
discharged at the time she was seen by the medical team in the 
morning, even though it was repeatedly explained to her that her 
discharge paperwork and medications needed to be organized and 
that this would require some time. Per RN report, patients's 
husband demanded that she remove the IV. RN removed IV with 
strict instructions for patient to remain in room so she could 
return with medications and discharge instructions. RN returned 
to room 15 minutes later to find that patient and family had 
left without discharge instructions or prescriptions for her 
medications. RN informed discharging MD immediately who called 
patient multiple times at her home phone number at that time and 
the day after discharge, instructing her on the answering 
machine to return to the hospital for her discharge 
instructions. MD's calls were not returned. Her prescriptions 
were called into her ___ pharmacy listed in OMR, and this 
was relayed to patient through phone messages at her home phone. 
The sudden departure of the patient from the hospital without 
discharge instructions lends credence to the fact that her 
multiple admissions CHF exacerbations may be due in part to 
medical non-compliance. In patient RN and MD staff made multiple 
attempts to contact patient and have been unsuccessful to date 
at the time of signing of this discharge summary. Patient does 
have ___ at home, but should follow up with her outpatient 
cardiologist for medical reconciliation as soon as possible to 
prevent future hospitalizations.

# HCAP: Patient initially presented with high fevers and 
hypotension. Investigation for infectious source revealed 
consolidation on CXR consistent with pneumonia. Treated with 
vancomycin and zosyn, but he still continued to have fevers, 
persistent leukocytosis and worsening oxygen requirement, 
needing a non-rebreather at one point. Tobramycin and 
doxycycline were added on ___ and ID was consulted. Patient 
improved significantly after addition of tobramycin/doxycycline, 
with mental status back to baseline. Tobramycin and doxycycline 
were discontinued on ___, given that ID felt that the 
percentage of GNRs not covered by zosyn is small, and he may 
simply require a longer duration of treatment with zosyn (i.e. 
he has not necessarily failed zosyn treatment). Additionally it 
was thought he may have been occasionally aspirating causing 
fevers and hypoxia. Patient has continued to do well with 
resolution of his leukocytosis and his last documented fever 
occurred on ___. Given that his MRSA screen returned 
positive, he will continue on Zosyn and Vancomycin through 
___.

secondary to infection as patient's mental status improved on 
antibitoics. CTA negative and EEG negative as well.

hemodynamically stable with regards to his anemia. Anemia likely 
secondary to bone marrow suppression in the setting of sepsis.

 Urine culture preliminarily grew GNRs and patient was

very nonfocal symptoms.  Incontinence is baseline, UA was 
equivocal but patient did note suprapubic tenderness on exam.  
She was empirically started on Ceftriaxone in the ED and 
subsequently transitioned to oral Bactrim on the floor.  She 
additionally was given fluids as above.  Urine culture was sent 
and preliminarily growing GNRs.  

# Sore throat:  Patient noted some symptoms concerning for a 
pharyngitis, had cough, hyperemia on exam without exudates or 
significant lymphadenopathy.  Given febrile illness at 
presentation and patient's altered mental status, throat swab 
was sent to rule out Group A strep which was negative.  Thought 
to be viral pharyngitis and no further treatment was needed.

Discharge Instructions:
No contact sports for 4 months
No sports for 4 weeks

ACTIVITY:  
 o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.  
 o You may climb stairs.  
 o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.  
 o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.    
 
 HOW YOU MAY FEEL:  
 o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.  
 o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.  
 o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.  
 o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon.    
 YOUR BOWELS:  
 o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.  
 o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.  
 PAIN MANAGEMENT:  
 o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".  
 o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 
 
 o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.  
 o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before 
your pain gets too severe.  
 o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.  
 o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.  
 o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.  
 If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:  
 - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours  
 - pain that is getting worse over time  
 - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101  
 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure caring for you. You were admitted for 
abdominal pain. We believe this is related to your pancreatic 
duct stones. We did an MRCP which showed that you did not need 
an ERCP or stent, which is good.

******

We also found you to have a condition called "adrenal 
insufficiency". It is not totally clear why you have this, and 
you will need further workup as an outpatient to find out more. 
We started you on a steroid (prednisone) to replace the hormone 
your body is not making. 

Medicines
Adrenal insufficiency is treated with medicines every day. 
Medicines can be taken in pill form or by injection, depending 
on your need. Glucocorticoids: One type of medicine you must 
take every day is type of steroid called a glucocorticoid. This 
type of steroid (different from the “body building” steroids) is 
necessary for allowing the body to metabolize fuel, although it 
also helps regulate inflammation, stabilize blood pressure and 
has many other effects in the body. Your medicines may be 
ordered as:
___ hydrocortisone
___ cortisone acetate
___ prednisone, or
___ dexamethasone, also known by the brand name ___

___ crisis can happen when your body's need for cortisol 
changes and the amount you take is not enough. Signs of an 
adrenal crisis are: Nausea and vomiting Abdominal pain Severe 
weakness or collapse Headache, dizziness or fainting Change in 
alertness or confusion Fever and chills Low blood pressure Fast 
heart rates, or going into shock
Treatment for Adrenal Crisis
If you have one or more of these signs, Dexamethasone can save 
your life, so carry doses with you at all times. You should have 
2 or 3 prefilled syringes of dexamethasone. Have one at home, 
one at work, and one you carry with you all the time. Keep the 
medicine at room temperature. Avoid hot or very cold 
temperatures, and keep it away from sunlight, and water. Refill 
your prescription when you use a dose, after the expiration date 
or one year after having the medicine filled, or if the medicine 
is cloudy or colored .

If your fever is 100.4°F or higher, then double your dose.
• If your fever is 102°F or higher, then triple your dose.
• If you experience vomiting and/or diarrhea, then double or 
triple your dose depending on severity. Take a double dose for 
mild to moderate symptoms and a triple dose for severe symptoms.
o If you vomit, wait half an hour, and repeat the dose. If you 
are vomiting and cannot keep the medicine down (vomiting less 
than one hour after the dose), you need to administer injectable 
hydrocortisone (Solu-Cortef) or dexamethasone, and contact your 
physician. Do not delay the injection; give the medicine first, 
and then call your doctor to discuss when you need to be seen. 
Drink small amounts of clear sugar-containing liquids 
frequently.

For your safety, you should get and wear a medical alert 
bracelet or necklace that states you have Adrenal Insufficiency. 
Apply for a medical alert bracelet or necklace. Wear your 
medical alert jewelry at all times. Carry with you a wallet card 
that has your doctor’s name, phone numbers, medicines you take 
and how to help you in an emergency. If you have one or more 
signs of adrenal crisis, or feel sick, take a dexamethasone 
injection, and call your doctor right away. Tell your coworkers, 
family and friends about how to help you if you have adrenal 
crisis. If someone finds you unconscious, have them give you 
dexamethasone right away. Then call ___ for help.

********
You are currently off of your spironolactone because your 
potassium is a little elevated and this medicine can worsen 
that. You may be able to resume this soon after clearance by 
your doctors. 

******
You are on opioids and benzodiazepines. We would recommend 
tapering one or both of these medications, as they are 
potentially very risky together for overdose. We are sending you 
with a script for an opioid reversal agent if needed in case of 
accidental overdose.

You were admitted to ___ following a witness seizure and with 
multiple injuries including bilateral frontal contusions, rib 
fractures, a right clavicle fracture, and spinal fractures.  You 
are now ready to return home to recover. 
* Your injury caused rib fractures which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

Brief Hospital Course:
___ YOM with alcoholic cirrhosis c/b encephalopathy, mesenteric 
and portal vein thrombosis, prior variceal bleeding, frequent 
falls and gait imbalance admitted to the MICU with sepsis, found 
to have UTI and recurrent hepatic hydrothorax.

# Sepsis (with urinary source). Patient febrile, tachycardic and 
leukopenic on arrival with urinary vs pulmonary source and 
lactate of 4 and 20% bands on repeat Diff. His blood pressure 
was close to his base line.  Initially broad differential was 
entertained and he was treated with broad spectrum Linezolid and 
Meropenam given his allergy history.  Patient received 3L IVF in 
ED and 1L albumin upon arrival to the MICU. Patient had a 
central line and a thoracentesis upon arrival to the MICU.  
Pleural fluid demonstrated transudative per Lytes Criteria.  He 
was subsequently found to have Proteus UTI.  Linezolid 
discontinued, meropenem continued until sensitivities came back 
on Proteus, then switched to ciprofloxacin.  No further 
hypotension; in review of outpatient records, SBPs in ___ are 
normal for him. He was treated with 7 day course of antibiotics. 
Blood cultures were negative. CXR initially showed no PNA; 
subsequent study read as a new LUL density that could be 
aspiration or PNA; however, pt remained afebrile, without cough, 
no CP, no leukocytosis, and 2 thoracentesis specimens both 
without evidence of infection, so it was thought unlikely that 
the patient has a true pneumonia an dhe was not treated for 
this.  Home midodrine for known orthostasis at increased dose of 
7.5mg TID was continued.
.  
# Right Pleural Effusion: During this hospitalization had 
thoracentesis x2 both showing transudative fluid, likely 
recurrent hepatic hydrothorax as no evidence of focal 
consolidation to raise suspicion for paraPNA as transudate via 
lights. Effusion re-accumulated after initial thoracentesis 
despite titrating up diuretics.  After second thoracentesis, 
remained small but stable.  Fluid cultures remained negative.  
By definition at this time, his effusion is not refractory given 
it had re-accumulated in setting of holding diuretidcs.  If 
effusion persists/becomes by definition refractory, options 
include repeated thoracentesis, transjugular intrahepatic 
portosystemic shunt placement, pleurodesis, and surgical repair 
of defects in the diaphragm.  Continued furosemide 40mg and 
spironolactone 100mg daily.

# Cirrhosis: No evidence of decompensation during this admission 
as LFTs at recent baseline and patient without encephalopathy.  
Continued 40mg PO Lasix, plus 100mg spironolactone,rifaximin, 
lactulose.
  
# Normocytic Anemia. No evidence of GI source in the MICU with 
guaiac negative stool on presentation. Hct had dropped from high 
___ to 31 initially, likely dilutional in the setting of IVF 
resusciation + bone marrow suppression in setting of concurrent 
infection.  Hemolysis labs with normal LDH, no haptoglobin 
available, Tbili within recent baseline.  Hct improved from 31 
to 38 and has been stable.

# Atrial fibrillation. CHADS20/CHADS2VAS1. Currently patient in 
AF with rates in 60-70s. No anticoagulation in setting of 
comorbidities and frequent falls.

# Hyponatremia. Stable and at recent baseline; likely due to 
cirrhosis with vasodilation and low perceived circulating volume 
to kidneys, leading to release of ADH. Free water restriction to 
2L. 
.  
# Protein calorie malnutrition: Evaluated by nutrition and found 
not to be taking in enough calories. Dobhoff in place and the 
patient is tolerating tube feeds well, now at goal.  ___ was 
kept in the stomach (not post-pyloric) due to repeated 
placements of the tube without success in post-pyloric 
placement.  Given he was tolerating well, kept in stomach.  He 
was monitored closely for signs of re-feeding syndrome. 

# Alcohol abuse: Last drink 2 days prior to admission.  
Initially on CIWA but did not score.  Maintained on MVI, 
Thiamine, Folate.

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
for monitoring and evaluation of her right lower quadrant pain 
and leukocytosis given concern for ovarian torsion. 
.
She underwent a CT, which showed no evidence of appendicitis and 
a right adnexal cystic structure measuring up to 4.7cm; torsion 
could not be excluded. A pelvic ultrasound showed a 
heterogeneous structure in the right adnexa measuring 4.1 x 4.0 
x 4.1 cm without clear visualization of the right ovary, 
possibly suggestive of ovarian torsion. She then underwent MRI, 
which showed a 4.4cm hemorrhagic right ovarian cyst, no evidence 
of torsion, multiple foci concerning for endometriosis, and no 
abscess or ___. Her pain was attributed to the ruptured cyst.
. 
Her pain was controlled with oral percoset, with IV dilaudid for 
breakthrough pain. Her leukocytosis improved over the course of 
admission; she did not receive antibiotics during her admission. 

.
She was maintained on her home medications for her hypertension 
and cardiomyopathy.
. 
By hospital day 2, her pain was controlled with oral pain 
medications, she remained afebrile throughout her 
hospitalization, and her physical exam was reassuring. She was 
discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow up 
scheduled.

Discharge Instructions:
Activity
•You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we 
recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours to avoid 
bleeding from your groin.
•Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise 
should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding 
from your groin.
•You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
•Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) 
days after your procedure.
•You make take a shower.
Medications
•Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
•You have been instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a 
day and Brilinta. If so, do not take any other products that 
have aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain 
Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office.
•You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
•If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again 
three (3) days after your procedure.
Care of the Puncture Site
•You will have a small bandage over the site.
•Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and 
gently peeling it off.
•Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
•You may use a band-aid if you wish.

What You ___ Experience:
•Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
•Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
•Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few 
weeks.
•Fatigue is very normal
•Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
•Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the puncture 
site. 
•Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
•Constipation
•Blood in your stool or urine
•Nausea and/or vomiting
•Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
•Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
•Seizures
•Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
•Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Mr. ___ presented to ___ to address his non-healing right 
first toe amputation site. On ___, he underwent a right lower 
extremity angiogram with superficial femoral artery stent 
placement via a left groin access site. The procedure was 
uncomplicated; please see the operative note by Dr. ___ 
full details. He tolerated the procedure well and was brought to 
the PACU in good condition and subsequently transferred to the 
surgical floor. He then went to the operating room with the 
podiatry team on the following day, ___, for resection of the 
nonhealing area of the right first metatarsal head. 
Post-operative foot x-ray, microbiology, and labs were 
reassuring. He again tolerated this procedure well and was 
brought to the surgical floor in good condition. His Coumadin 
was restarted on ___ and Plavix for his lower extremity stent 
was begun on ___. Other home medications were continued through 
his hospital course. On ___, he was evaluated by physical 
therapy and recommended for rehab placement given the continued 
need for teaching on use of the heel weightbearing surgical 
shoe. Initially, Mr. ___ adamantly declined to go to a 
rehab facility and stated that he would only be willing to go 
home. In light of this, the vascular surgery team came to the 
bedside in the early afternoon of ___ to help determine his 
capacity to decline rehab. At that time he did not appear to 
have capacity to fully understand his treatment instructions and 
consequences of declining rehabilitation, and was felt to be 
making some comments that exhibited poor understanding (for 
instance, stating that his surgical team was "not very good 
engineers") and perseverating on lost items which were later 
clarified by family members to have been lost during a previous 
admission several months ago. At this time the patient 
repeatedly insisted he was planning to leave the hospital, 
including potentially by himself, and would not discuss his 
plans to get home with the surgical team in any detail. The 
surgical team then spoke with family members to ask for 
assistance in discussing treatment options with the patient, and 
psychiatry was consulted for a formal evaluation of the 
patient's capacity to leave against medical advice and decline 
discharge to a ___ facility. Later in the afternoon, 
the patient changed his mind and at the time of psychiatric 
evaluation was no longer asking to leave against medical advice. 
His family arrived at bedside and with their encouragement on 
the evening of ___ he agreed to be discharged to a 
rehabilitation facility.

On ___, discharge to rehabilitation was arranged. The patient 
remained hemodynamically stable and afebrile. He was able to 
tolerate a regular diet, pain was well-controlled on oral 
medications, and foot dressing and heel weightbearing surgical 
shoe were in place. Discharge instructions were discussed with 
the patient prior to discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had an 
angiogram and stent placement to improve blood flow to your 
right leg as well as surgery to remove unhealthy tissue at the 
previous amputation site on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital and go to rehab to continue regaining strength and 
completing teaching on how to use your post-surgical heel 
weightbearing shoe.  Please follow the recommendations below to 
ensure a speedy and uneventful recovery.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
GROIN PUNCTURE SITE CARE
For one week:
•Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot 
tub.
•Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around 
the puncture site. 
•Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. 
•Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the 
puncture site. 
You may remove the bandage and shower the day after the 
procedure.  You may leave the bandage off. 
You may have a small bruise around the puncture site.  This is 
normal and will go away in one-two weeks. 

ACTIVITY 
•You should keep your surgical site elevated. This will prevent 
swelling of the tissue.
•It is very important that you put no weight or pressure on 
your first toe and metatarsal region with activity or at rest to 
allow the wound to heal properly. 
•You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if 
applicable.  It will take time to learn to use the heel 
weightbearing shoe. 
Because of your groin puncture site, for the first week:
•Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 
pounds
•Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold 
your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles.   Take care not 
to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, 
or moving your bowels.

MEDICATION
•Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  
•You may be prescribed narcotic pain medication on discharge 
which  can be very constipating.  If you take narcotics,  please 
also take a stool softener such as Colace.   If constipation 
becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest an additional 
over the counter laxative. 

•You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
•You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.
•After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
•Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on wound.    If there is no drainage, you 
may leave the incision open to air.  
•Any staples or sutures that require removal will be removed by 
your podiatrist at your follow-up appointment. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
•Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your toe surgical 
site
•Redness, swelling or warmth in your foot
•Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/surgical site pain
Call ___ in an emergency such as:
•Sudden, brisk bleeding or swelling at the groin puncture site 
that does not stop after applying pressure for ___ minutes
•Bleeding that is associated with nausea, weakness, or 
fainting.
Call the vascular surgery office (___) right away if 
you have any of the following. (Please note that someone is 
available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week)
•Swelling, bleeding, drainage, or discomfort at the puncture 
site that is new or increasing since discharge from the hospital
•Any change in sensation or temperature in your legs
•Fever of 101 or greater
•Any questions or concerns about recovery from your angiogram 

It was our pleasure taking care of you and we wish you a speedy 
recovery!

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of rheumatoid 
arthritis on remicade, prednisone, MTX who presents with 
sciatica down L leg.  Originally, she was thought to have L hip 
pain but was later felt by Dr. ___ to have adequate ROM without 
pain and an exam more suggesttive for sciatica.  Her course has 
been notable for waxing and waning pain requiring IV morphine.  
MRI was attempted on ___ but the machine was too small to 
accommodate MS. ___ so arrangements were made for exam to happen 
on the ___ on ___ and it revealed L4-L5 disc 
herniation.  Neurosurgery was consulted and recommended 
conservative treatment as well as IV Decadron.  Since she is 
already on steroids (Prednisone 15 mg daily), after discussion 
with Dr. ___ was decided to go up on the Prednisone 
to 60 mg po daily for a few days.  She continued to have severe 
pain, and was seen by the pain service.  Narcotic pain 
medications were increased, with mscontin, oxycodone, and 
neurontin.  She continued to have pain, and had injections in 
her SI joint, GTB bursa, and her ultimately in her epidural 
space.  With treatment, she improved, was able to ambulate, and 
was discharged home.

Her remaining medical problems included rheumatoid arthritis, 
obesity, ulcerative proctitis, hypertension, asthma, 
osteoporosis all remained stable, and she was continued on her 
home medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with a h/o of LV diastolic dysfunction, HTN, and COPD 
who presents with one week of shortness of breath likely due to 
COPD flare. 
.
#COPD flare: Possible etiologies for her SOB were MI, CHF flare, 
Asthma, COPD flare, pulmonary hypertension, pneumonia, 
interstitial lung disease, PE. Her EKG was unchanged from the 
prior EKG, showing a possible old septal infarct and no changes 
consistent with PE. She had no chest pain and cardiac enzymes 
were also negative. Her SOB is likely not related to MI. CXR 
showed no pulmonary edema and BNP was also normal, suggesting 
she had no CHF, even though her history of increased dyspnea 
when she reclines sounds like CHF. She has wheezes and 
eosinophilia, suggestive of asthma, but she does not have a 
prior history of asthma.  Pulmonary hypertension would most 
likely have a more insidious onset than her presentation. 
Pneumonia is possible, but CXR is clear and her sputum is clear. 
She was given albuterol and ipratropium nebs as well as a 
prednisone taper from 60mg. A course of azithromycin was started 
on ___. ABG showed respiratory acidosis with metabolic 
compensation and additional metabolic alkalosis likely due to 
lasix. Her shortness of breath improved on these treatments, 
suggesting that her SOB was a COPD flare. Her outpatient 
cardiologist was contacted and wished to defer further cardiac 
workup (likely a nuclear stress test) to the outpatient setting. 
At the time of discharge, she was feeling at her baseline; she 
was discharged with follow up appointments with her 
pulmonologist and cardiologist and to complete a steroid taper.
.
#Microcytosis: ___ TIBC, ferritin, and TRF were normal and 
HCT was normal. Smear is consistent with Thalassemia trait or 
sideroblastic anemia.  Thought likely to be  thalassemia trait, 
but further workup may be required.
.
#HTN: Continued HCTZ. Her blood pressures remained within normal 
limits. 
.
#CK elevated: CK is chronically elevated in Ms. ___. Troponin 
was negative this admission. CK elevation is common among 
___ americans and also seen in hypothyroidism. Ms. ___ 
TSH is normal, so likely this is a benign elevation.
.
#Elevated HbA1c: HBA1c was 6.3.  Fingersticks were not elevated 
on prednisone. ___ will check fingersticks.
.

.

steroids. She was also given a bowel regimen and omeprazole.

Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with a PMHx of 
neurofibromatosis complicated by spinal astrocytoma and

Chronic stage IV sacral/hell ulcers:
Chronic osteomyelitis

subjective fever and elevated CRP.  ___ RN was concerned about 
her ulcer given interval increase in size and tunneling noted, 
though no apparent clearly infected tissue requiring debridement 
was seen.  In terms of other infections, she had no resp 
symptoms and CXR was negative.  LFTs were neg.  Her Ucx grew E. 
coli which has been a colonizer.  Her CRP remained elevated 
compared to her most recent hospitalization.  MRI demonstrated 
likely chronic osteomyelitis.  ID was consulted to help 
determine a treatment plan given her medical complexity and 
history of poor adherence to treatment and ability to follow 
treatment plans in the outpatient setting. It was thought that 
best plan was to treat for the soft tissue infection and have 
aggressive wound care. She was recommended to start 
linezolid/moxifloxacin for a 10d course but she refused 
linezolid for unclear reasons. She was trialed in house on

tolerated well other than some mild nausea. Her CRP trended down

was very helpful. She was advised repeatedly about the 
importance of aggressive wound care as being a necessary part of 
any solution to her chronic infection, and was set up with a new 
___ for daily wound care dressings (as she had previously not

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with a PMH significant for 
cervical DJD and EtOH abuse, discharged ___ after cervical 
spinal fusion admitted in the setting of witnessed fall and

# Altered Mental Status: This was likely related to 
polysubstance abuse. He was found by EMS with altered mental 
status with an empty pill bottle at his side. Urine and serum 
toxicology were positive for ethanol, benzodiazapines and 
cocaine. He was admitted to the ICU given the potential for a 
difficult intubation if needed, given his recent neck surgery. 
He did not require intubation, and his sensorium cleared. He 
required valium on a CIWA scale, but no longer required valium 
by the time he transferred to the floor. He did have a history 
of hallucinations and blackouts on withdrawing from alcohol, and 
he was started on thiamine and folate. During his 
hospitalization he briefly refused to wear his neck brace.He was 
seen by the psychiatry service to evaluate competency and he was 
deemed competent to make this decision. He then decided to 
comply with wearing the neck brace. 
.
# s/p Fall: This was likely related to polysubstance abuse. He 
was found by EMS with altered mental status with an empty pill 
bottle at his side. Urine and serum toxicology were positive for 
ethanol, benzodiazapines and cocaine. The patient had recently 
had C3-C7 fusion (___). He was seen by the ortho spine 
service, and the determination was made that he had no acute 
fracture, but should continue to wear a heard collar until he 
was seen by orthopedics for follow up as an outpatient. His pain 
was controlled initially with tylenol, ultram and flexoril. 
Oxycodone was eventually reintroduced and he was discharged on 
the same dose recommended by orthopedics following his C3-C7 
fusion. 
.
Polysubstance Abuse: The patient has a history of alcohol, 
cocaine and narcotic abuse. He engaged in extreme drug seeking 
behavior during his hospitalization, including throwing himself 
on the floor in order to obtain higher doses of narcotic 
medications. He was discharged on the same dose recommended in 
the post surgical period by his orthopedic surgeon. He was seen 
by social work and routed to an outpatient addictions support 
facility. 
.
? Bipolar d/o, anxiety d/o: The patient was seen by psychiatry. 
They felt that it was difficult to evaluate the patient's 
reports of anxiety disorder or bipolar disorder in face of his 
active substance abuse. He endorsed worsening of his anxiety and 
moderate weight loss. He should have a TSH checked as an 
outpatient with further work up of this complaint in the 
outpatient setting.

=======================================================
Seizure Safety Plan

Patients at risk for seizures that involves loss of 
consciousness must avoid:
- Driving (for 6 months after a seizure...
            ...UNTIL A PHYSICIAN STATES THAT IT IS ___
- unattended baths, unattended swimming,power tools, heavy 
machinery
- ladders, high platforms, roofs
- any other activity that could pose a safety risk if there was 
a loss of consciousness or uncontrolled body movements

For any seizure involving loss of consciousness, do the 
following:
1. Don't panic - take a deep breath
2. Look at the clock to see what time the seizure started.
3. If the patient is shaking for more than 5 minutes - or has 
repeated seizures without returning to normal in between, call 
___ this is an emergency.
4. As much as possible, move things away from the patient's ___ 
to avoid injury
5. Use pillows or towels to protect the from injury
6. Put them on a bed, couch, or the floor ON THEIR SIDE. This is 
to avoid a condition called aspiration pneumonia, when vomit 
goes into the lungs.
7. DO NOT PUT ANYTHING IN THEIR MOUTH. Patients don't swallow 
their tongues despite the old wives tale. However, putting 
things inside the mouth could lead to choking hazard.
8. When the seizure is over and you are sure they are safe, 
please call the neurology clinic to let us know about a seizure.

rhythm of unclear etiology, and remained asymptomatic through 
out admission with no lightheadedness, dizziness, syncope, chest

response to abdominal pain, but another possibility is verapamil 
accumulating in her system in the setting of renal failure 
(verapamil is hepatically metabolized, but the metabolite is 
still active and renally excreted).  Throughout hospitalization, 
her heart rate remained in the ___ with no intervention.  
Her verapamil held as an inpatient and restarted as an 
outpatient as it is beneficial for diastolic heart failure.

takes furosemide 20mg po daily and did not seem volume 
overloaded today.  By CXR, did not appear volume overloaded 
either.  Furosemide was held while she was an inpatient in the 
setting of ARF but will be restarted as an outpatient at half 
the dose (now at furosemide 10mg po daily).

CABG ___.  Her current sharp epigastric pain does not sound 
anginal in nature.  She has nonspecific TWI on EKG and negative 
troponin x2.  She was continue simvastatin and ASA, but her

explained by dehydration (hypovolemic hyponatremia and decreased

improved to 1.6 from 2.8 on the day of discharge and her 
hyponatremia and hyperkalemia resolved.

Discharge Instructions:
•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•Your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, you must keep 
that area dry for 10 days. 
•You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
•Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with history of osteoporosis, DVTx3 presents 
after a mechanical fall on ___ with LOC, found to have a right 
patellar fracture. 

ACUTE ISSUES: 
# Mechanical fall - Patient suffered a mechanical fall due to an 
uneven sidewalk.  She did not hit the back of her head, no loss 
of consiousness.  The patient developed intractable 
nausea/vomiting with headache; serial noncontrast head CTs in 
the ED were not revealing of any head bleeds and her symptoms 
were felt to be consistent with a post-concussive syndrome. The 
patient did suffer a R patellar fracture per below.  

# R patellar fracture - Found to have non-displaced comminuted R 
patellar fracture, with flexor and extensor function intact. 
___ brace was placed by Orthopedics; brace is to remain 
locked in full extension at all times and the patient is 
weight-bearing as tolerated.  She did not require surgical 
intervention while hospitalized and pain was well controlled 
with Tylenol.  She will follow-up with Ortho as an outpatient.  
The patient was evaluated by ___ while in-house and will require 
rehab due to decreased functional mobility.

#Rib fractures - patient complained of left sided rib pain. Rib 
series revealed non displaced new ___ and ___ left rib fractures 
with healing 10th rib fractures.  She only required Tylenol for 
pain control. 
 
# History of multiple DVTs - all DVTs seem to have been 
provoked. She was told by her outpatient hematologist that she 
will require lifelong anticoagulation because of her history of 
multiple DVTs.  She was continued on her home Coumadin and her 
INR was within therapeutic range.  She is interested in further 
discussion regarding the new anticoagulants.

# RLE swelling - Patient noted to have some increased RLE 
swelling thought to be ___ fracture and placement ___ 
brace.  INR was therapeutic throughout hospitalization and RLE 
ultrasound showed no evidence of a DVT.

CHRONIC ISSUES: 
# Hypothyroidism - continued home levothyroxine 125 mcg daily

# HLD - continued on simvastatin 20 mg daily

***TRANSITIONAL ISSUES***
-Patient expressed interest in different anticoagulation 
regimens.  She should discuss these issues with her outpatient 
hematologist. 
-Please consider a repeat CXR in 1 month to assess for 
resolution of LLL infiltrate seen on left rib series X-ray, to 
assess for resolution of the infiltrate, if clinically 
indicated.
-f/u with Orthopedics Clinic

 of necrotic bone; Primary DIP joint arthrodesis; Repair of the 
ulnar digital nerve; nail bed repair.

 fracture down to bone with excision of necrotic fragments. 
Repair of the ulnar digital nerve, Repair of the radial digital 
nerve, Repair of the radial digital artery, Nail bed repair
 which the patient tolerated well. For full details of the 
procedure please see the separately dictated operative report.

condition and after satisfactory recovery from anesthesia was 
transferred to the floor. The patient was initially given IV 
fluids and IV pain medications, and progressed to a regular diet

patient's home medications, with the exception of lisinopril and

course including reasons to call the office or return to the

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER HAND/UPPER EXTREMITY SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for hand surgery. It is normal to 
feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
Nonweightbearing to the left upper extremity in a splint to be 
worn until follow-up appointment 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.
-- you will continue to take the antibiotic AUGMENTING for the 
next 5 days to protect you from infection, please be sure to 
take this medication as prescribed

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed

SPLINT CARE:
- Do NOT get splint wet
- Please remain in the splint until follow-up appointment.  
Again, please keep your splint dry at all times.  If you have 
concerns regarding your splint, please call the clinic at the 
number provided.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever ___ 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted with abd pain/N/V and elevated blood pressures. 
On the morning of ___, a code blue was called for his roomate 
and during the commotion he started complaining of severe chest 
pain. Pt was diaphoretic and grabbing his chest with BPs of 
220/120.  EKGs showed LVH without acute ST changes and pt was 
endorsing confusion. He was taken for stat head CT that did not 
show any acute hemorrhage. BP came down to 180/100 (bilaterally) 
with nitropaste, IV metoprolol and 10mg IV morphine. Pt was 
transferred to the ICU for concern of hypertensive emergency and 
he had a PICC placed prior to being started on a nitro gtt.   Pt 
had four sets of negative cardiac enzymes, stable creatinine and 
EKGs.  On further examination, he was not endorsing any 
confusion and was transitioned to his home regimen of Valsartan, 
Diltiazem with low dose labetalol. Pt was examined serially in 
the ICU and was inconsistent in describing his symptoms. It was 
unclear whether the acute pain episode was actually consistent 
with his recurrent epigastric pain, chest pain or an acute 
anxiety attack.  Given his history of anxiety/stress

His acute renal failure has been further precipitated by his high dose linsinopril therapy and lasix. There were no symptoms of obstruction and a renal ultrasound showed no hydronephrosis. He never appeared volume overloaded. He is anemic at baseline but had no bone pain or hypercalcemia to suggest myeloma. His urine sediment was bland with no evidence of casts or dysmorphic reds, as reported by lab tech. His acute kidney injury was compliacted by hyperkalemia, for which he received insulin, Ca, and kayexalate in the ED. Lisinopril and lasix were held while in-house. No urine eosinophilias were found. He received a total of 2.5L of supplemental IVF which greatly improved his Cr trending down to almost near his baseline in 24 hours. Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with history of atrial 
fibrillation, aspiration, CHF, and CKD who was brought to the ED 
by family for agitation.

# Agitation: Patient had been refusing medications, has not 
bathed, and had been throwing things per family members. UA on 
admission not consistent with UTI. Patient also with 
leukocytosis, however this has persisted since her last 
hospitalization. Patient does have a history of aspiration but 
was without cough and found to have CXR with no evidence of 
focal consolidation. EKG was without ischemic changes. On 
further history, it seems that patient is more demoralized and 
upset by the lack of independence that she has at home. She is 
oriented x 3 and converses appropriately when examined. ___ 
evaluated her and recommended 24 home supervision. Patient was 
evaluated by psychiatry who agreed that patient was not 
depressed or delirious but rather simply frustrated by home 
situation. 

# Disposition: Patient had prolonged hospitalization as 24 hour 
home supervision could not be provided. She was evaluated by 
social work and palliative care as well as geriatrics. She was 
determined to have capacity and thus, her own medical 
decision-making. Despite her wishes to go home without 24 hour 
supervision, she was held in order for this care to be 
established to provide a safe discharge plan. Multiple family 
meetings were held with primary care taker, grandson ___, 
primary team members, social work, and others. Ultimately, with 
geriatrics and hospice liaison presence and aid, a plan for 24 
hour supervision was instituted and thus, patient was deemed 
safe for discharge home with services.

# Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated from last admission. This 
was attributed to continued aspiration. Decreased to 8.0 on 
___.

CHRONIC ISSUES:
# HYPERTENSION: Continued home amlodipine, metoprolol.
# CHF: Currently not symptomatic and on room air. Of note, the 
patient was discharged home on O2 at last admission. Continued 
home Lasix 20mg PO daily.
# AFIB: Not on anticoagulation. Continued on fractionated 
metoprolol while hospitalized and discharged on long-acting 
metoprolol. 
# Anemia: Likely secondary to slow GI bleed and CKD. Patient 
required transfusions during last hospitalization but declined 
further intervention or workup with egd/colonoscopy. H/H 
remained stable during this admission.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old ___ speaking man with a 
history of seizure disorder (on carbamazapine), who initially 
presented to an OSH after being found down by family and 
transferred from ___ after having 2 witnessed 
generalized tonic clonic seizures s/p Ativan, Keppra, 
fosphenytoin and intubation. He was initially admitted to the 
MICU for monitoring, then once stable, transferred to the 
neurology service for further care. His course was complicated 
by fevers and traumatic foley placement.

#Status epilepticus:
The patient has an underlying seizure disorder on carbamazepine 
300 mg BID, though his level was subtherapeutic. His medications 
were managed by PCP in ___ and ___ reported poor 
medication compliance. He was initially intubated and sedated 
from the outside hospital and was able to be extubated on ___. 
There was concern for infectious trigger given fever to 103 in 
the ED. He was initially started on broad spectrum antibiotics 
with vancomycin, ceftriaxone, ampicillin and acyclovir, though 
CSF not clearly consistent with bacterial or viral etiology, so 
antibiotics were discontinued on ___. He did intermittently run 
fevers, though improved even after stopping antibiotics. Other 
possible triggers for his seizures include medication 
noncompliance and ETOH withdrawal (ETOH history unclear). 
Initiated levetiracetam 1000 mg BID, held home carbamazepine 300 
mg BID. No additional seizures on the Neurology floor. Prior to 
discharge, patient was counseled that he should not drive, 
operate heavy machinery, or drink ETOH, he was amenable.

#Fevers: 
Etiology of the patient's fevers are unclear. CXR relatively 
unremarkable. UA without evidence of infection. LP unremarkable. 
Low suspicion for other source. Treated with broad spectrum 
antibiotics (see #status epilepticus). His antibiotics were 
stopped on ___ and he remained afebrile. 

#Altered mental status: 
Patient was altered and agitated in the ICU, especially after 
extubation. Unclear etiology. Possibly related to ETOH 
withdrawal, though unclear how much patient drinks. Placed on 
phenobarbital taper which was discontinued prior to discharge 
given low suspicion for withdrawal. ___ also be ICU delirium, 
especially given re-directability with family members and waxing 
and waning features. In the ICU he was loaded with 
phenobarbital, kept on precedex, and started on Seroquel, with 
good response. He was able to be weaned off precedex on ___ and 
remained AAOx3. He had no additional episodes of agitation and 
Seroquel was discontinued.

#Acute respiratory failure:
In the setting of agitation and status epilepticus, intubated 
for airway protection and hypercarbia. Extubated on ___ and 
remained without hypoxemia.

#Traumatic foley removal
Patient pulled out foley on ___ and passed blood clots on ___. 
He was kept on serial bladder scans to ensure was not clotting 
off. Urology follow-up was scheduled prior to discharge.
