Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service 
after undergoing exploratory laparotomy, total abdominal 
hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, plasmajet 
ablation of peritoneal and diaphragmatic disease, mobilization 
of splenic flexure, splenectomy, omentectomy, and cystoscopy. 
Please see the operative report for full details.  

*)Postoperative course: Her post-operative course is detailed as 
follows. Immediately postoperatively, her pain was controlled 
with acetaminophen and an epidural. Her epidural was managed by 
the Acute Pain service. On postoperative day 3, her epidural was 
removed and she was transitioned to PO dilaudid and 
acetaminophen. Her urine output was also adequate and thus her 
foley catheter was removed.  Given that she had surgery 
involving the bowels, her diet was slowly advanced. She was 
maintained on a diet consisting of clears with supplements and 
toast and crackers. Her diet was advanced to a regular diet on 
___ when there was evidence of return of bowel function on 
postoperative day 7.  

By post-operative day 8, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

*) ___ erythema c/f cellulitis
___ there was erythema noted near patient's incision 
concerning for cellulitis so the the area was marked and a 7 day 
course of cephalexin 500mg PO q6H was started. The erythema 
decreased over the next few days and completely resolved by 
___ staples were also removed prior to discharge on 
postoperative day 9.

*) Hypertension
On postoperative day 3,  she developed hypertension which 
progressed to an episode of hypertensive urgency to 190/104. She 
received 20mg IV labetalol but her BP did not decrease so she 
then received 40mg IV labetalol and her blood pressure dropped 
to 151/76. The same day she was re-started on her home HTN 
medication (losartan 50mg PO Daily). On postoperative day 4, she 
remained hypertensive and had another episode of hypertensive 
urgency to 183/93 and received 20mg IV labetalol but her blood 
pressure did not decrease. She then declined another dose of IV 
labetalol and remained hypertensive (160s-180s/70s-90s). She 
remained on losartan 50mg PO Daily.
On postoperative day 5,a formal medicine consult was initiated 
and per their recommendations she was started on hydralazine 
25mg PO q8H x2 days and amlodipine 5mg PO Daily. On posop day 6, 
she experienced a hypotensive episode to 103/65 and her 
amlodipine was decreased to 2.5mg PO Daily. Patient's blood 
pressure remained in 140s/80s upon discharge. She was discharged 
with amlodipine 2.5 mg daily and her losartan was discontinued 
due to the fact that it did not appear to affect her blood 
pressures while she receive it. Patient was advised to follow up 
with her PCP in one week for hypertension medication management. 


*)Post splenectomy vaccinations
Patient was given vaccines on postoperative day 8 for hemophilus 
influenza B, pneumococcal 13, and meningococcal. She was 
instructed to have her PSV23 vaccine administered within ___ 
weeks or before she starts chemotherapy. She was also given post 
splenectomy precautions and counseled heavily on warning signs 
of possible infection. 

*) Post splenectomy thrombocytosis
Patient's platelet count continued to trend upward while she was 
in the hospital after her surgery. On day of discharge, her 
platelet count was 1356. Thrombocytosis is an expected change 
after a splenectomy. Per medicine team and heme onc team, there 
is no indication for intervention for thrombocytosis. Patient 
was expectantly managed for this given that platelet counts can 
take ___ days post splenectomy to peak. 

*) VTE prophylaxis: Patient received heparin while she was 
inpatient. After her epidural was removed, she was started on 
lovenox. She was discharged with enough lovenox to complete a 28 
day postoperative course of daily lovenox prophylaxis at home. 
While in the hospital, she also had pneumoboots on and was 
performing incentive spirometry.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after 
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well 
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be 
discharged home. Please follow these instructions: 

Abdominal instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  We recommend you take 
non-narcotics (i.e. Tylenol, ibuprofen) regularly for the first 
few days post-operatively, and use the narcotic as needed. As 
you start to feel better and need less medication, you should 
decrease/stop the narcotic first.
* Take a stool softener to prevent constipation. You were 
prescribed Colace. If you continue to feel constipated and have 
not had a bowel movement within 48hrs of leaving the hospital 
you can take a gentle laxative such as milk of magnesium.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (tylenol) in 24 
hrs.  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 12 
weeks.  
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 6 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.
* It is safe to walk up stairs.  
.
Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* You should allow your steri strips to fall off on their own.   
If they are still on after ___ days from surgery, you may 
remove them.  

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  

.
Call your doctor at ___ for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  
* chest pain or difficulty breathing 
* onset of any concerning symptoms 

*** Lovenox injections:
* Patients having surgery for cancer have risk of developing 
blood clots after surgery. This risk is highest in the first 
four weeks after surgery. You will be discharged with a daily 
Lovenox (blood thinning) medication. This is a preventive dose 
of medication to decrease your risk of a forming a blood clot. 
*Your last injection of lovenox will be on ___.

***Constipation:
* Drink ___ liters of water every day.
* Incorporate 20 to 35 grams of fiber into your daily diet to 
maintain normal bowel function. Examples of high fiber foods 
include:
Whole grain breads, Bran cereal, Prune juice, Fresh fruits and 
vegetables, Dried fruits such as dried apricots and prunes, 
Legumes, Nuts/seeds. 
* Take Colace stool softener ___ times daily.
* Use Dulcolax suppository daily as needed.
* Take Miralax laxative powder daily as needed. 
* Stop constipation medications if you are having loose stools 
or diarrhea.

***Hypertension 
*Your blood pressure went as high as the 190s/100s while you 
were in the hospital. The losartan 50 mg that you were 
originally prescribed for your hypertension was discontinued as 
it was not controlling your blood pressure. You were started on 
amlodipine 2.5 mg daily for blood pressure control and you 
responded well to it. Please follow up with your PCP in the next 
week for an appointment to better titrate your medications. 

***Post Splenectomy Vaccination
*After having a splenectomy, you are at increased risk of 
infection for certain microorganisms. You were given the 
meningococcal vaccine (Menactra), pneumococcal 13  valent 
vaccine (Prevnar 13), and Haemophilus B conjugate vaccine. 
*YOU ARE DUE FOR YOUR PNEUMOCOCCAL 23 VALENT VACCINE in the next 
___ weeks, BEFORE your chemotherapy starts. PLEASE ensure to get 
vaccinated with the pneumococcal 23 valent vaccine in ___ weeks. 
It is very important that you receive this vaccination in a 
timely manner before your chemotherapy starts. 
*Please call ___ if you are having trouble scheduling 
your vaccination.

precautions and warning signs. In summary, warning signs of 
infection to be aware of and to call the office at ___ 
or 911:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency  Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours.  Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

discharge, warm to touch, fever).

note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain.  Call 
the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character. Be sure to 
empty the drain frequently.  Record the output, if instructed to 
do so.

site clean and dry otherwise. ___ apply a drain sponge as 
needed.

water.

prevent pulling or dislocation.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is an ___ year-old ___ man with PMH of 
bladder cancer s/p radical cystectomy/ileal conduit at ___ on 
___, gastric adenocarcinoma, ?metastatic disease, HTN who was 
sent in from ___ with AMS and fevers, septic shock and material 
in pelvis of uncertain etiology (post surgical vs. fecal) 
intubated on arrival for respiratory distress, extubated on 
___, improving on antibiotics but with an unidentified source 
of infection still and then transferred to ___ 
which is his site of primary care. 
_____________________________
ICU COURSE (___):

#SEPTIC SHOCK: 
Presented with fevers, AMS, hypotension requiring pressors 
(Levophed) and rising leukocytosis. Most likely urologic or 
intra-abdominal source. No cough prior to intubation despite 
patchy opacity in L lower lobe. Recent cystectomy at ___ with 
leukocytosis, fevers, AMS, UA c/f infection but to be expected 
with new ileal conduit per urology. Per discussion with urology, 
not clear that this is purely urologic source. S/p 4L NS IVF and 
vanc/cefepime in ED ___ ___. Lactate 5.5 initially in ICU. S/p 3 
additional L (1L NS, 2 L of LR) IVF in ICU and lactate improved 
to 2.1 by ___ @ 0700. Spoke to ___ about draining a fluid 
collection around his surgicel in the abdomen at the site of his 
cystectomy, but they didn't feel that there was anything 
drainable. Colorectal surgery recommended at CT A/P with rectal 
contrast to look for rectal perforation as a source of 
infection. The study was performed and there were no signs of 
perforation. The patient's fevers and hypotension continued 
overnight despite continued treatment with Vancomycin and Zosyn. 
At this point it was felt to be very unlikely that the fluid 
collection was the source of infection given that the surgery 
was weeks ago, and it would be odd for the collection to become 
infected so far out. Urine culture was negative, so the 
kidneys/conduit were not felt to be a source. Bacterial 
translocation was considered as a possibility, though no blood 
cultures were positive at discharge. Because the patient was 
improving clinically with stable hemodynamics and a lactate back 
down to 1.0, ID felt that it was appropriate to stop micafungin 
and vancomycin and to just continue Zosyn. 

Pressors at discharge: Levophed @ 0.08

#RESPIRATORY FAILURE: 
Intubated on arrival to ICU for tachypnea ___, unable to speak 
in full sentences. CXR with patchy left base opacity but per 
report no cough recently. Was on propofol/fentanyl for sedation, 
pressure support ventilation, and extubated successfully on ___ 
AM. 

#COAGULOPATHY: 
INR 1.5 and PTT 51 from previously normal. Concern for DIC in 
setting of septic shock, but platelet count was stable and 
fibrinogen was elevated. No evidence of hemolysis as haptoglobin 
was elevated, LDH was low and Tbili was low. Likely secondary to 
the patient's septic shock or antibiotic use, as his INR was 1.0 
on arrival so does not appear to be nutritional and there was no 
evidence of liver failure (His alkaline phosphatase was elevated 
and then came down with treatment, which was possibly from 
cholestasis of sepsis).

#ACIDOSIS: 
Initially anion gap with a large base deficit, then non-anion 
gap. Felt to be a combination of the elevated lactate which was 
resolved and all of the chloride the patient received from 
normal saline, causing a hyperchloremic acidosis (patients with 
ileal conduits take up chloride in exchange for bicarb as the 
urine passes through). 

#BLADDER CANCER S/P RADICAL CYSTECTOMY: 
Underwent procedure at ___ ___. Operative report in chart. 
Urology consulted and saw the patient in the ED, and their main 
recommendations were to get colorectal surgery involved to 
evaluate for a bowel perforation. 

#ANEMIA: 
Hgb 8.8 on admission, at previous baseline per ___ records. 
Dropped to 6.7 on ___ AM. Looked dilution and gave 1U pRBC and 
the patient responded appropriately to Hgb 7.8. 

#ACUTE KIDNEY INJURY: 
Cr 2.1 on admission, baseline appears 1.2-1.3 per ___ records. 
Likely pre-renal component in setting of sepsis, although this 
may be the patient's new baseline as he remained stable at Cr 
2.1. 

#CODE STATUS: Patient urgently intubated on admission with 
consent from HCP who is the patient's son ___ 
listed HCP) ___. Per code status conversation on 
admission to ___, patient was DNR, OK to intubate. At 
preparation for discharge, code status was re-addressed with 
HCP, particularly in-relation to whether the patient would want 
re-intubation should he develop new respiratory distress. HCP 
was undecided about code status and wanted to readdress with his 
father. Therefore, code status upon transfer to ___ 
___ was FULL CODE as agreed by patient's HCP.

PATIENT SUMMARY

___ with a PMH of polysubstance use disorder, MVA ___ c/b T12

ACUTE ISSUES
===============
# Leukocytosis
# Fevers
Patient presenting with fevers, leukocytosis and LUQ pain found 
to have bacteria and WBCs on UA. Patient has history of 
recurrent urinary tract infections in setting of ileal conduit 
urinary diversion c/b L anastomotic stricture requiring L 
indwelling PCN (___). His recent urine cultures grew 
pan-sensitive Klebsiella on ___, pan-sensitive E. Coli on ___, 
VRE on ___. He grew MDR pseudomonas in ___. He was most 
recently treated with fosfomycin Q72 hours last dose on ___. He 
was planning to follow up with ID to discuss suppressive 
therapy, but he did not make it to appointment. Case discussed 
with ID in ED and they recommended Meropenem given multiple 
medication allergies and history of resistant infections in the 
past. Urine culture with colonic bacteria (sample likely taken 
from ostomy). Discussed revision of L ureteral stenosis w/ 
urology as frequency of UTIs has increased; however, patient 
does not want to pursue any surgical management, therefore 
urology signed off. ID consulted and did not feel picture was 
c/w UTI. Meropenem was stopped and patient watched off ABx. 
Leukocytosis and fevers resolved, but patient again became 
febrile and developed leukocytosis on ___, this time with 127 
WBC in urine that also grew enterobacter cloacae. Patient was 
treated with fosfomycin, and then was started on fosfomycin 
prophylactic treatment on ___. 

# Bacteruria
Patient chronically colonized, likely due to complex renal 
anatomy of ileal conduit and PCN. Patient was started on 
fosfomycin prophylaxis this hospitalization, and asymptomatic 
bacteruria does not require treatment. 

# Paranoia, hallucinations, delusions 
Patient endorsing auditory hallucinations. Feeling scared and 
unsafe. Initially believing that he was raped while in the 
hospital, but later acknowledging that this was a delusion. 
Intermittently refusing diagnostic and therapeutic 
interventions. Was initially verbally threatening staff with 
violence, but has since become more calm and cooperative, 
although did have continued issues with behavioral disturbances, 
yelling, and cursing.

Urine tox positive for cocaine x2 (although patient denies use). 
Searched room given cocaine positivity and threats of violence 
to staff, which was very upsetting to the patient. On room 
search, found some home medications, but no illicit substances 
or weapons. In the week after the room search, patient 
voluntarily told his nurse that he had found some of his home 
oxycodone in his sock that he had forgotten about. This was 
placed in the lock box, and due to concern that the patient was 
pocketing his doses of oxycodone while in house, this was 
switched to a liquid form. 

Patient continued to speak with pressured speech and was 
paranoid, at one point claiming to have been raped by staff; 
however, later noting that this was "all in my head" and that 
his voices had told him this. Patient was treated with 
olanzapine, which was titrated to 10 mg PO BID with 5 mg PRN for 
breakthrough agitation. On discharge he still reported hearing 
voices, however he "realizes these are fake" and thinks that 
they have decreased since he started the olanzapine. He was 
discharged with home ___ psych nurses as well as olanzapine PO 
BID, with the plan to eventually taper as an outpatient at the 
discretion of outpatient psychiatry. 

# LUQ Pain
# Nausea
# Constipation
Patient reporting LUQ pain on presentation. He declined a CT A/P 
in the ED. Pain began after a fall about a month ago, so may be 
musculoskeltal in origin. Initial abdominal US was unremarkable: 
did not show any evidence of splenic or hepatobiliary pathology. 
KUB ___ without evidence of obstruction but did show large 
stool burden. Patient eventually underwent CT, which again 
showed large stool burden Abdominal pain and tenderness may 
therefore be secondary to constipation. Patient was offered 
several medications for constipation, but mostly refused. He 
states that he refuses bowel regimen because after the car 
accident he could no longer feel below the waist, and is 
incredibly embarrassed by frequent accidents. He told nursing 
that he did manual disempaction every morning. This was not 
witnessed by nursing or anyone on staff. He did eventually have 
a few large bowel movements that were witnessed by nursing, with 
slight resolution of his abdominal pain, and nausea. He 
attributes the bowel movements to the liquid form of oxycodone, 
and is very resistant to taking the liquid oxycodone. He was 
counseled about constipating effect of opiates and need for 
bowel regimen, and he was encouraged on discharge to make sure 
he has a bowel movement every day.

Brief Hospital Course:
# s/p Sepsis secondary to Salmonella/Coag Neg Staph:  Resolved.  
The patient was admitted to the MICU intubated in septic shock, 
rhabdo, metabolic acidosis, ARF, and aspiration PNA, and was 
resuscitated with IVF and pressors. He received broad spectrum 
antibiotics, initially with Vancomycin and Zosyn.  A CT scan 
revealed pancolitis, and Surgery was consulted and recommended 
conservative management.  Patient's blood cx grew out coag neg 
staph and salmonella; group B strep was cultured from the 
sputum.  Antibiotics were tailored to CTX/Vanco/Flagyl. When he 
stabilized off pressors, the CVL which was placed at ___ 
___ in the R subclavian artery was removed with angio 
guidance by Vascular Surgery; a stent was deployed due to 
ongoing extravasation.  The patient was weaned to minimal vent 
settings and extubated successfully on HD 5.  Patient was 
transferred to the floor and treated with a 10 day course of 
Vancomycin and Ceftriaxone (later switched to cefepime - 
described below), which was shorter duration than the total 14 
days anticipated because of patient's pancreatitis, 
hepatotoxicity, and rash (acute generalized exanthematous 
pustulosis).  Patient had fluctuating WBC count during his stay 
(likely reactive), but surveillance cultures remained negative, 
and was afebrile and hemodynamically stable.  

#. Transaminitis/Cholestasis/Pancreatitis:  Patient was septic 
on admission and required pressors.  On admission, patient had a 
transaminitis consistent with shock liver that improved during 
the course of his admission.  Patient had been improving during 
hospitalization, but was noted to have an elevated WBC count 
(18) on ___.  Patient had been afebrile, hemodynamically 
stable, but there was concern for possible intra-abdominal 
abcess vs worsening colitis (noted on admission) that raised 
suspicion for occult infectious process.  On ___, patient was 
noted to have elevated amylase/lipase, elevated direct bilirubin 
and Alk phos, and was noted to be somnolent.  Given the 
multiorgan system involvement, there was concern for possible 
drug toxicity.  Patient had a Valproate level and Carbamazepine 
level checked as the doses of these medication had been 
increased on ___ to his home doses.  These medications were 
taped off over several days.  CT abdomen, MRCP, RUQ u/s were 
performed and were unremarkable as to the etiology of the 
patient's hepatic and pancreatic involement -- no evidence of 
ductal dilation or gallstones.  Patient's cholestatic markers 
continued to trend upward over several days and so hepatology 
was consulted.  Hepatology attributed patient's cholestatic 
pattern to Zosyn that he received in the MICU earlier in his 
course.  Patient's cholestatic markers have stabilized and 
amylase,lipase were no longer trended when patient improved 
clinically. 
.
#. C difficile Colitis: Patient developed C diff colitis on ___ 
with a fever, increased white count, and tachycardia. Patient 
was transiently re-admitted to the MICU where he received 
fluids, and was started on flagyl and vancomycin. Vancomycin was 
stopped (see below) and patient continued on Flagyl for planned 
21 day course.  
.
# Acute Generalized Exanthematous Pustulosis:  On ___ patient 
was noted to have an erythematous rash involving his inguinal 
region that was initially thought to be a candidal cellulitis.  
On the following days, was noted to be spreading, and was noted 
to be involving patient's trunk and back.  Dermatology was 
consulted and diagnosed this rash as acute generalized 
exanthematous pustulosis, attributed to use of B lactam 
antibiotics in the past.  Patient was treated with emollient and 
triamcinalone cream. Vancomycin oral was started in the setting 
of C diff and patient broke out in a new rash, so this was 
stopped. Rash was not nearly as severe as prior AGEP and 
resolved within 3 days.   
.
#Acute on Chronic Renal Failure:  Patient was admitted with a Cr 
of 5, thought to be related to patient's septic shock.  
Patient's Cr had trended downward to 1.5 during the admission, 
likely secondary to ATN. Per his PCP, baseline ___ is around 1.4. 
Additionally, patient reports known history if diabetes 
insipidus due to prior Lithium use. 
.
# Pancolitis:  Unclear etiology.  Patient was in septic shock 
when he was initially admitted and was noted to have pancolitis 
on CT scan on admission.  It was thought that patient may have 
developed this from hypotension, but unclear.  Of note, patient 
was noted to have salmonella in his blood cultures.  Patient was 
followed by general surgery who recommended conservative 
management.  A repeat CT Abd/Pelvis shows interval improvement 
in colonic wall.  Patient's PCP was contacted and faxed 
colonoscopy records dating ___ years ago that showed normal 
colon then.  
.  
#History seizure disorder:  Patient has a history of seizure 
disorder and has been on carbamazepine and valproic acid at 
home.  On admission, patient's home doses of these medications 
was unclear and was started on low doses of each.  Patient's 
pharmacy was contacted.  His home dose (as of ___) was 
Carbamazepine 400/600, and Valproic Acid ___.  Patient 
was started on this medication on ___.  Patient was noted to 
have hepatotoxicity/pancreatitis on ___, but it is unclear if 
these medications are related to his state.  Patient had been 
previously on these doses as an outpatient and had been 
refilling regularly.  Neurology was consulted to help taper 
these medications.  He was taped off over several days and was 
started on Keppra for seizure prophylaxis. He had a therapeutic 
Keppra level prior to discharge.  
.
# Bipolar disorder: Transitioned to risperidone in house and 
patient did well on this regimen. Psychiatry was involved and 
felt that patient should have neuro-psych evaluation after acute 
medical issues resolved, but felt that Bipolar was likely at 
baseline at the time of discharge. 
.
#. Hypothyroid: Thyroid studies checked in the setting of 
hypothermia and diarrhea. TSH 16, but free T4 normal at 1.2 
likely indicating sick euthryoid in the setting of patient's 
multiple other medical problems. Plan to retest TSH as 
outpatient after acute issues resolve by PCP.
.
# RCC: Mass noted on MRI abdomen in house. It appears patient 
has known ___ based on prior records from ___ and is s/p RFA 
___. Plan for patient to follow up with Dr. ___ at 
___ with plan for Q3 month CT scans for first year.

___. Regarding HCP, patient has indicated that Cousin

brother is willing to be HCP, but patient is refusing. For now, 
if there are any issues, will have to use next of kin ___

Brief Hospital Course:
Primary Reason for Hospitalization: Patient is a ___ year-old, 
previously healthy, incarcarated male with history of IVDU, who 
initially presented with a peroneal abscess and concern for 
perineal necrotizing fasciitis, and multiple septic lung emboli. 
The perineal wound was drained and showed no necrotizing 
fasciitis. Cultures from the wound and blood grew MRSA and 
patient began treatment with vancomycin. A wound on patient's 
anterior left shin was incised and drained as well. He required 
a brief ICU stay for respiratory distress but was never 
intubated. His fever and shortness of breath resolved and 
patient went to ___ floor. TEE showed no vegetations and patient 
was discharged to complete a 6-week course of vancomycin.
.
ACUTE CARE:
.
1. MRSA bacteremia: Patient had a perineal and buttock wound 
that grew MRSA in culture and blood cultures that grew MRSA as 
well. He was found to have radiographic evidence of septic 
emboli and was febrile with shortness of breath as well. He was 
started on a course of IV vancomycin. Patient received a TEE 
which showed no vegetations. He was discharged to complete a 
6-week course of vancomycin.
.
2. Perineal wound and other buttock and shin wound: Patient's 
initial complaint was a tender, erythemetous wound involving the 
scrotum and perineum. It started off as a pimple-sized lesion 
and grew to involve a large area. Surgery evaluated and debrided 
the wound because of concern for necrotizing fasciitis, which 
was not present. The wound grew MRSA and patient recieved 
vancomycin and wet-to-dry dressing changes. The additional 
wounds on the left anterior shin and left buttock were incised 
and drained and had daily dressing changes as well. He was 
dishcarged with instructions for antibiotics and dressing 
changes to continue.
.
3. Lung Septic Emboli: Patient had septic emboli to the lung as 
evidenced by chest CT. He showed no neurologic signs suggesting 
brain lesions. Because of the lung lesions, patient had a period 
of respiratory distress requiring Bipap in the unit. This and 
patient's fever resolved with antibiotics and he did not require 
intubation. He was weaned to room air and previous pain 
experienced with respiration was greatly decreased. IP evaluated 
patient for a small loculated pleural effusion associated with 
the involved lung, and it was found to be too small to drain. 
CTPA showed no PE on this admission as well
.
CHRONIC CARE:
.
1. IVDU history: Patient was informed about the possibility of 
infection with IVDU and he was made aware that the current 
damage to his veins from this history interferes with vascular 
access.
.
TRANSITIONS IN CARE:
1. FOLLOW UP: Patient will follow up with the medical system 
within the department of corrections. He should receive follow 
up with infectious disease upon finishing the 6-week course of 
vancomycin.
2. CARE TRANSITION: Per request of the DOC, patient will be 
transferred to ___ to complete his inpatient care. 
he should be continued on heparin SC for DVT ppx.
3. VACULAR ACCESS: Patient has a PICC line placed. It was 
initially placed 2 cm too far in as seen on CXR, but was 
retracted 2cm and is OK to use for IV abx now that it is 
properly positioned.

initial systolic upstroke is brisk. The peak systolic velocity 
of the main renal artery has decreased from 122 to 81 cm/s.

renal vein is patent and shows normal waveform.

intrarenal arteries.  Main renal artery peak systolic velocity 
has also decreased from 122 to 81 cm/s.

and concurs.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
 # Dyspnea: The patient was admitted for dyspnea and hypoxia. 
She was initially requiring an NRB and was admitted to the ICU 
overnight. She was thought to be volume overloaded and diuresed. 
Her hypoxia improved. She was found to be 84% on RA per her 
hematologist prior to admission. On transfer to the floor, she 
was 89% RA, 95% 2L. During her hospital stay, her shortness of 
breath improved subjectively although she still had significant 
dyspnea on exertion. She received albuterol and ipratropium nebs 
q6hours; no steroids or Advair. She was switched from Tiotropium 
and Advair to Combivent 4 times daily as her symptoms and 
oxygenation appeared to improve with frequent nebs. Beta-blocker 
was stopped to avoid bronchospasm. HCTZ was started instead for 
high BP. The pulmonary team followed her during her stay.  Echo 
showed no evidence of systolic or diastolic heart failure. PFT's 
showed obstrutive pattern with increased lung volumes and 
reduced diffusion capacity. Her work up included: ANCA- 
negative; ___ 1:40 (negative); Galactomanin and B-glucan 
negative; IgE <2.0; absolute peripheral eosinophilia of 300; 
Hypersensitvity panel negative. High Resolution Chest CT showed 
diffuse multifocal ground-glass opacities in a predominating 
mosaic pattern, worse when compared to ___. The patient 
was taken to VATS. VATS showed numerous non-necrotizing 
granulomas c/w sarcoidosis. Vit D levels and ACE-I were WNL. She 
was stared on Prednisone 40mg daily. She was started on 
bisphosphate and calcium w/ vit D. She was also started on 
bactrim for PCP ___.
.
# Purulent discharge from port-a-cath: On ___, the lumen of 
the patient's port-a-cath was found to be draining discharge. 
The IV nurse drew back from the lumen of the port and suctioned 
out yellow fluid. A wound culture was sent, found to have 3+ 
PMN's but no organisms grew. Blood cultures were sent were 
negative. The patient showed no sign of systemic infection w/o 
fevers, leukocytosis or chills. As the patient had not used the 
port-a-cath for treatment in 6+ months, the port-a-cath was 
removed at the same time as the VATS.
.
# Hypertension: Beta-blocker was stopped to reduce any 
contribution to obstructive lung disease. HCTZ was started 
instead. ACE-i was considered but the patient appeared to be in 
acute renal failure. She had no secondary indication for an 
ACE-i.
.
# ARF: Baseline creatinine from OSH records appears to be 
0.9-1.0. On admission, she had a creatinine 1.2 which rose to 
1.5 then came down to 1.1. The acute renal failure may have been 
due either to IV contrast or diuresis on admission. No further 
diuresis was performed and her ins/out kept even.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with CAD s/p CABG, diastolic CHF, 
hypertension presented with nausea, vomiting, new right bundle 
branch block, and elevated cardiac markers consistent with 
NSTEMI.

# NSTEMI: Patient presented initially with abdominal discomfort 
(described as the sensation of needing to belch) and nausea with 
negative CT abdomen and KUB.  Trops and CK-MB were elevated and 
ECG showed new rate dependent RBBB.  Abdominal pain is likely 
her anginal equivalent.  She was started on heparin gtt for 
48hrs, plavix loaded, given full dose of aspirin and 
atorvastatin 80mg. Her beta blocker was uptitrated to maintain 
rates in ___.  A TTE was performed to look for new wall 
motion abnormalities and it showed a reduced EF of 40-45% (new) 
and regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction c/w possible 
CAD. Pt's pain resolved and CK-MD down trended to within normal 
limits.  Coronary intervention was discussed with pt and decided 
to undergo cardiac cath which showed left main and 3 vessel 
native CAD. One of her 4 bypass grafts (SVG to OM) is occluded. 
She was managed medically and was discharged on aspirin, plavix, 
metoprolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin 80mg.  

# Right bundle branch block: rate dependent. Discharged on beta 
blocker.
 
# Hypertension: Continued amlodipine, clonidine and metoprolol. 
HCTZ was discontinued. She had episodes of hypertension to 170s 
when she was due for clonidine doses. One such episode was 
associated with recurrence of her abdominal discomfort that 
resolved with her dose of clonidine and resolution of 
hypertension. ECG at that time did not show ST changes. ACEi was 
started for more consistent blood pressure control in the 
setting of systolic dysfunction. 

# Congestive Heart Failure: now with decreased EF in setting of 
ischemic insult. She was medically managed and discharged on 
ASA, plavix, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and an ACEi. 

# Chronic kidney disease:  Baseline creatinine is around 1.3. 
She was pre-hydrated with IVF before and after cardiac cath and 
her creatinine remained around baseline. 

Transitional issues:

- If ongoing chest/abdominal pain, consider evaluation with 
stress test

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ yo man with chorea-acanthocytosis (known to Dr. 
___ and one possible prior event concerning for a 
seizure in ___ who was brought into ___ for evaluation of an 
episode of stiffening concerning for seizure. His seizure event 
was witnessed by his nurse (___) at ___. She describes the 
event as follows: "He woke after 8:00 am, was helped to the 
bathroom and returned to his bed. Soon
after she was called into the room and the patient was stiff in 
all extremities, eyes were open and his gaze was fixed straight. 
He was not responsive to voice or tactile stimuli but was 
localizing to sternal rub. No jerking noted by her but the PCA 
noticed some twitching prior to her arrival. He was turned to 
his side
and the episode lasted about 5 min. He closed his eyes and 
continued to be unresponsive for another 5 min until EMS arrived 
when he started to open eyes in response to his name. He had a 
similar episode on ___ but ___ his nurse was not present at 
that time." In the ED he was initially drowsy and lethargic to 
response to commands, far from his baseline. He was given a 1mg 
Keppra load and started on 500mg BID dosing out of concern for 
seizure with post-ictal confusion. Impression was that his 
presenting episode may be a second episode of possible seizure 
with a history of neurological disorder that predisposes him to 
epilepsy, warranting initiation of low dose AED. Within several 
hours, his mental status returned to baseline. He underwent 
routine extended EEG which did not show any epileptiform 
discharges (official read pending). His was not orthostatic 
(Lying SBP 121 > standing 108, HR 84-->71) He did not have any 
further clinical seizure-like activity but was noted to have two 
brief oxygen desaturation events overnight, lasting less than a 
minute. Impression for his desaturation is likely related to 
respiration/apnea vs nocturnal seizures. To facilitate event 
capture, he was discharged with an ambulatory EEG to evaluate 
for seizure activity overnight, which may warrant further 
uptitration of Keppra in the outpatient setting. Decision was 
made to do this in the outpatient setting, as he expressed 
wishes to return to his home environment as soon as possible.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital for an episode of confusion 
with possible stiffening of your extremities. This event 
occurred after you woke up but was not associated with 
standing/sitting and as such was not clearly correlated to 
changes in blood pressure. This is your second episode within 3 
months, which raises concern for possible seizures. Your 
disease, Choreoacanthocytosis, increases your risk for seizures. 
As such, we started you on a seizure medication (KEPPRA).  We 
evaluated your brain activity on EEG for 60 minutes and saw 
NORMAL brain activity without signs of seizure activity. No 
further seizure-like activity was noted and your mental status 
returned to baseline within a few hours.

We monitored you overnight and detected 2 very brief episodes of 
low oxygen.  This could be related to your breathing during 
sleep or possibly (and less likely) due to short lasting 
seizures during sleep. To better characterize these spells, we 
ordered a 24-hour ambulatory EEG monitoring so that we can see 
how you sleep and how your brain functions during sleep while 
you are in your home environment.  You will need to return to 
EEG lab for removal of leads on ___ at 11 AM.  Your home 
facility ___ at ___ was notified to arrange 
transportation.

Your primary neurologist Dr. ___ has been notified of your 
hospitalization and medication changes. Please follow up with 
him as scheduled below. 

Your sincerely,
___ Neurology team

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was re-admitted to the hospital for observation after 
presenting to the hospital with subjective fever at home to 
100.4 and worsened dysuria and urinary frequency 5 days after 
discharge to home from her kidney transplant hospitalization. 
Her urinalysis was essentially normal and her urine culture did 
not grow any organisms. Her WBC was normal, she made appropriate 
urine output, and she remained afebrile for > 24hrs. Her kidney 
graft function is excellent with Cr of 1.0. She has been 
adherent to her post-transplant regimen including a course of 
augmentin for an enterococcus urinary tract infection that has 
resolved from her original admission, and ciprofloxacin for 
pseudomonal coverage due to her donor having pan-sensitive 
pseudomonas bacteremia.  Her home medications were continued, 
including her immunosuppressive regimen and prophylactic 
medications. Tacrolimus level was 7.6 and her 2.5q12hr dose was 
not changed. She was tolerating a regular diet with stable 
symptoms and expressed her desire to return home. With 
assistance of her daughter's interpretation the patient was 
educated about expected post-operative discomfort and frequent 
voiding due to the re-expansion of the bladder. She is due for 
labs the day after discharge and expressed her understanding of 
this. She will have outpatient follow up with the transplant 
center this week.

Discharge Instructions:
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever > 
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability 
to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or 
eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, 
cloudy urine, swelling of abdomen or ankles, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

Bring your pill box and list of current medications to every 
clinic visit.

You will have labwork drawn every ___ and ___ as 
arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the 
transplant clinic (Fax ___ . CBC, Chem 10, AST, T 
Bili, Trough Tacro level, Urinalysis.

*** On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your Tacro 
until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacro with you so you may 
take your medication as soon as your labwork has been drawn.

Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.

You may shower. Allow the water to run over your incision and 
pat area dry. No rubbing, no lotions or powder near the 
incision. You may leave the incision open to the air. The 
staples are removed approximately 3 weeks following your 
transplant.

No tub baths or swimming

No driving if taking narcotic pain medications

Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.

Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
or Ensure.

Check your blood sugars and blood pressure at home. Report 
consistently elevated values to the transplant clinic

Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
medications which must be considered in medication management 
following transplant. Your medications were not changed, 
continue these as ordered. 

Consult transplant binder, and there is always someone on call 
at the transplant clinic with any questions that may arise.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions: Please call your surgeon or return to 
the emergency department if you develop a fever greater than 
101.5, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, 
pain unrelieved by your pain medication, severe nausea or 
vomiting, severe abdominal bloating, inability to eat or drink, 
foul smelling or colorful drainage from your incisions, redness 
or swelling around your incisions, or any other symptoms which 
are concerning to you.

Diet: Stay on Stage III diet until your follow up appointment. 
Do not self advance
diet, do not drink out of a straw or chew gum.

Medication Instructions:
Resume your home medications, CRUSH ALL PILLS.
You will be starting some new medications:
1.  You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain 
from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.
2. You should begin taking a Flintstones chewable complete 
multivitamin. No gummy vitamins.
3. You will be taking Zantac liquid ___ mg twice daily for one 
month. This medicine prevents gastric reflux.
4. You will be taking Actigall 300 mg twice daily for 6 months. 
This medicine prevents you from having problems with your 
gallbladder.
5. You should take a stool softener, Colace, twice daily for 
constipation as needed, or until you resume a normal bowel 
pattern.

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

central line placement to begin therapy. His admission weight

units per kilo equalling 51.2 million units IV every 8 hours

digoxin to achieve a therapeutic digoxin level to assist with

treated with additional dose of IV digoxin with eventual
improvement in his heart rate control. At that time he had
associated dyspnea with his elevated heart rate. On treatment

rate subsequently increased to the 150 range again. He
remained asymptomatic without hypotension noted. He had no
dyspnea noted. He did receive additional digoxin IV with
improvement in his heart rate control. Digoxin was decreased
to 125 mcg p.o. daily given decreased renal clearance
anticipated with IL-2 therapy. At the time of discharge his
heart rate was in the 90-120 range with occasional PVCs and
he was planned to restart Toprol XL for the week that he was
home. He will discontinue that on the ___ before his
admission.

Other side effects during this week included fatigue; rigors
improved with Demerol; and occasional dyspnea on exertion.
His glucoses were fairly well managed off metformin.

Discharge Instructions:
•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•You may wash your hair only after after your wound check with 
Dr ___. Your sutures are dissolvable •You may shower before 
this time using a shower cap to cover your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
••Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ h/o stage IIA pancreatic cancer (recently completed ___ 
cycle gemcitabine), severe AS (valve area <1.0cm2), Afib (on

NSVT, plan for valvuloplasty.

#Decompensated diastolic heart failure related to severe AS: On 
exam he appeared volume overloaded with crackles and 1+ ___ 
edema. OSH CXR suggesting CHF. He was given 20 IV lasix BID at 
OSH and he was requiring 5L facemask (at OSH 2.5L). His O2 
requirement here was worsening and he was transferred to the CCU 
when he had to be put on a non-rebreather. There was initial 
concern that the patients heart failure may have acutely 
worsened due to his aortic stenosis. Repeat echo was performed 
and showed a valve area of <1cm and a preserved ejection 
fraction of 45%. The patient initially had been planned to have 
a palliative valvuloplasty however on reevaluation it was 
unlikely to provide the patient with much relief given the valve 
area and mean gradient. The patient was diuresed with a lasix 
drip and IV lasix  bolus of 40mg to which he put out well too. 
He was diuresed with caution given his aortic stenosis. The 
patient was 92kg on admission and 88kg on transfer from the CCU. 


#Hypoxemia- Patient had presented to the hospital with dyspnea 
had a new oxygen requirement. It was thought to be 
multifactorial. This included aspiration, possible pneumonia and 
heart failure. The patient was triggered during his hospital 
stay for acute desaturation into the ___ and required to be 
placed on a rebreather. His physical exam was notable for severe 
anterior and posterior crackles. The patient was transferred to 
the ICU. He was kept on the rebreather and was not intubated 
given his code status of DNR/DNI. The patient was diuresed as 
per above. He was treated initially for aspiration pneumonia 
with broad spectrum antibiotics which was discontinued as it was 
thought he was suffering from aspiration pneumonitis.  His 
amiodarone was discontinued as it may have been resulting in 
additional pulmonary toxicity. Given his prolonged hypoxia with 
minor improvement with the above actions the decision was made 
to consult pulmonary. The suggested further work up and possible 
gemcitabine toxicity. The patient was started on IV solumedrol 
for 5 days. The patients oxygen requirement went down from 
rebreather to FiO2 80% on facemask. His crackles resolved on 
physical exam. The patients Beta Glucan came back positive. He 
was started on treatment for PCP with bactrim for 21 days  (___). The patient had daily CXR and LDH. High resolution CT 
scan was not performed as it was unlikely to change managment 
givne that patients chronic pancreatic cancer.  The patient was 
transferred to the MICU. The patient was given bactrim and 
continued on steroids with the thought that his hypoxia could be 
secondary to PJP, however after 3 days of treatment there was no 
improvement seen in the patient's oxygenation status.  The 
patient was maintained on nasal canula oxygen and a combination 
of high flow/non-rebreater/shovel mask with goal O2 saturations 
>80%.  On the day of discharge, the patient was made CMO and 
given small doses of morphine and ativan to help with air 
hunger.  Patient was satting between 80 and 96% on high flow 
face mask. 

#NSVT: Likely due to myocardial strain from severe AS. Pt had 
multiple episodes of polymorphic SVT since arriving to the 
cardiology floor. On ___, triggered for 1 min run of VT with 
loss of consciousness before spontaneously converting (normal 
lytes). His pacer rate was initially increased to 91 but 
subsequently decreased to 80 in the setting of a worsening O2 
requirement. He was loaded with amiodarone. After transfer to 
the CCY his amiodarone was discontinued as the patient had no 
more episodes of NSVT and there was concern that the amiodarone 
may be leading to pulmonary toxicity. Given the short duration 
of dosing it was unlikely to be causing pulmonary toxicity 
however given his fragile pulmonary system it was deemed safer 
to discontinue it. He appeared to be stable with the pacing at 
80. The patient was monitored after the amiodarone was stopped 
and did well with no repeat episodes. 

#Aspiration PNA/Pneumonitis: Pt had a witnessed aspiration event 
before transfer to ___. Otherwise he had been afebrile, had a 
normal white count, and CXR showed small area of increased 
density in the RLL, consolidation could not ruled out. He had 
been receiving IV clinda at OSH and was switched to levofloxacin 
on arrival to ___. This was further switched to ceftriaxone. 
When the patient triggered on the floor for hypoxia, the acute 
drop in his saturation was thought to be due to an aspiration 
event. The patient appeared to desaturate in the setting of 
having just received his medications. His antibiotics were 
broadened to vancomycin and cefepime and the patient was made 
NPO. Speech and swallow evaluated the patient and deemed him 
safe to eat. The broad spectrum antibiotics were discontinued 
after 72 hours given that he was afebrile and stable.

Discharge Instructions:
___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a 
new ileostomy placement is dehydration. The output from the 
stoma is stool from the small intestine and the water content is 
very high. The stool is no longer passing through the large 
intestine which is where the water from the stool is reabsorbed 
into the body and the stool becomes formed. ___ must measure 
your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output from 
the stoma should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If 
___ find that your output has become too much or too little, 
please call the office for advice. The office nurse or nurse 
practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the 
ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice 
your ileostomy output increasing, take in more electrolyte drink 
such as Gatorade. Please monitor yourself for signs and symptoms 
of dehydration including: dizziness (especially upon standing), 
weakness, dry mouth, headache, or fatigue. If ___ notice these 
symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room 
for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ may eat a 
regular diet with your new ileostomy. However it is a good idea 
to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made 
to ___ by the ostomy nurses.
___ monitor the appearance of the ostomy and stoma and care 
for it as instructed by the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ stoma 
(intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) should be 
beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times 
when touched and this should subside with time. The skin around 
the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the 
skin around the stoma for bulging or signs of infection listed 
above. Please care for the ostomy as ___ have been instructed by 
the wound/ostomy nurses. ___ will be able to make an appointment 
with the ostomy nurse in the clinic 7 days after surgery. ___ 
will have a visiting nurse at home for the next few weeks 
helping to monitor your ostomy until ___ are comfortable caring 
for it on your own.

If ___ have any of the following symptoms please call the office 
for advice ___:
fever greater than 101.5
increasing abdominal distension
increasing abdominal pain
nausea/vomiting
inability to tolerate food or liquids
prolonged loose stool
extended constipation
inability to urinate

___ will be discharged home on Lovenox injections to prevent 
blood clots after surgery. ___ will take this for 30 days after 
your surgery date. This will be given once daily. Please follow 
all nursing teaching instruction given by the nursing staff. 
Please monitor for any signs of bleeding: fast heart rate, 
bloody bowel movements, abdominal pain, bruising, feeling faint 
or weak. If ___ have any of these symptoms please call our 
office for advice or seek medical attention if there is an 
emergency. Avoid any contact activity while taking Lovenox. 
Please take extra caution to avoid falling.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ was readmitted after discharge following a right 
colectomy related to GI bleeding at the staple line caused by an 
medication error on our teams part. The patient was sent home on 
coumadin and prophylactic lovenox after very specific 
instructions on what the anticoagulation plane would be which 
was prophylactic lovenox only has he was no longer on warfarin 
and had been treated for a prior clotting event. We addressed 
this with our team. He recieved 3 units of blood in total and 
was monitored closely for continued bleeding. On ___ he had 
one bowel movement with old clot and no bright red blood. He was 
monitored closely. His diet was slowly advanced as his symptoms 
continued to improve. He was hemodynamically stable. There was 
no procedure to stop the bleeding, we waited and held 
anticoagulation and the bleeding subsided. On ___ he had 
two bowel movements that were old dark maroon blood. And on the 
day of discharge, he had a brown bowel movement and was stable 
and ready for discharge home on the appropriate anticoagulation 
plan. He was specifically told by this writer not to restart 
Warfarin at home. Dr. ___ explained to the patient in 
___ not to restart the warfarin.

Discharge Instructions:
You were readmitted after surgery for bleeding from your 
previous Right Colectomy. This was likely related to restarting 
your blood thinning medication to prevent blood clots. You were 
given blood when you were admitted and now your blood counts are 
stable. You are stable to return home. You should continue to 
monitor how you are feeling and for signs and symptoms of 
bleeding. Please call if you have any of the following symptoms: 
passing blood from your rectum or with bowel movements, 
dizziness, feeling faint, fast heart rate, weakness, bruising 
over your abdomen that has worsened, increased abdominal 
distension, increased abdominal pain. Please call if you are 
experiencing any concerning symptoms. You should restart the 
Lovenox on ___ and you will take this medication for 
a total of one month after surgery please call if there are any 
issues with the lovenox. 

You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures and a skin glue called 
Dermabond. These are healing well however it is important that 
you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any 
of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room 
if your symptoms are severe.  
You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of 
Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove 
them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team.

Please monitor your bowel function closely. Some loose stool and 
passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call 
the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: 
increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, 
prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation.  

You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 3000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication. Please do not take 
any ibuprofen or other antiinflammatory medications, this can 
contribute to bleeding. 

No heavy lifting greater than 6 lbs for until your first 
post-operative visit after surgery. Please no strenuous activity 
until this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. 
___.  
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities.
